text: Hummus is a must very creamy and nice flavors.  Greek salad was great with good salad dressing.  Low expectations but high results.

Oh my gosh, that shawarma sandwich was AMAZING. Glad I chose to pick up my watch on a lunch break, because the Oasis Cafe aroma led me to the back of the storefront to find this otherwise hidden gem. :D Ok prices for lunch in the Loop.

Great falafel. Very good hummus. Decent chicken shwarma. HORRIBLE pita. I've tried a dozen things from the menu, but have settled on the mixed combination with chicken shwarma for the past 50 orders. It's good! Except the pita, which is an abomination they should be disappointed in.

This place is seriously a hidden gem for lunch; it's in the back of a jewelry store. I, being the basic individual that I am, would never have even thought to stop by if I just passed this spot while walking but a coworker shared this awesome place with me.  There's always an Oasis Cafe sign placed outside the jewelry store during the day so you can find the place. Walk in and beeline to the back of the store where delicious food awaits. There's a daily special item each day and all days are good! My usual go-to is the mixed combo chicken though. It's 3 pieces of falafel AND chicken shawarma, rice, tomato and cucumber salad, and hummus with pita. It's a ton of food for like under $8!! I usually get two meals out of it.  The place has some seating so you can dine in. It's always busy during lunch but these guys are great and the line moves super fast. Definitely check this place out if your in the area!!

I have worked a few blocks away from this place and I am just now hearing about it recently by a friend who frequents the place.  It could be easy to miss as its in the back of a jewelry store on Wabash which I find quite interesting as you have to walk past the jewelry cases and people that work there to get to Oasis. They have the menu and specials plastered on the wall once you make it to the back. I am a lover of mediterranean/middle eastern food so this place is heaven for me and very reasonably priced. The most popular dish seems to be the Mixed Combination which is very good as it includes chicken shawarma over rice with hummus, salad and falafel...I love this stuff! I have also had the Kefta platter which is also good!  Do yourself a favor and get over here and grab a good mediterranean lunch. You can dine in or take out. They have a sign outside of the store so you can't miss it.
Great hole in the wall with sizable portions and good prices. Love their daily specials and the falafel is
some of the best food hidden downtown, you really don't want to miss this place!

After seeing this place located in the back of a jewelry shop I knew I had to try it.  The chicken shawarma lunch special is a pretty good deal but nothing really fantastic. The chicken, hummus, and falafel were all fine but a bit bland. For the price I'd expect a bit more honestly.

A great place to grab an authentic bite! As others have mentioned, it's tucked literally into the back of a jewelry shop (don't worry, there's a sign for it outside so you don't need to wander through every jeweler on the block).  The menu's got all the traditional options for Mediterranean you could ask for, and the food comes out lightning fast! Don't expect upscale anything, but it's simple and simply delicious. Great for a bite after checking out Cloud Gate!
Found this place through Yelp and it is a hidden gem. Found right in Jeweler's Row, nice spot to have a meal. Hope to visit this place again in the future.

There are so many better fast casual food options in the loop for the same price. Food was extremely bland and dry. I would rather eat the jewelry from the store you have to walk through to get here then eat here again.  By far the worst lunch I've had in Chicago.

It is fast, I will agree with that, but that is the only positive.  The food is tasteless and dry.  There are literally 100s of better fast fresh places in the loop and all of them actually serve fresh food.  I wouldn't eat here again if you paid me.

From the suburbs and was in Grant park with the family looking for lunch. Always looking for hole in the wall gems, and this place is one of those. Tasty food, generous portions for 10 bucks or less, and it was very fast. Don't worry about it being oddly inside a jewelry store- no one looks twice as you head back toward the restaurant.

I came back around noon on a Wednesday and did not have to wait any longer than a couple minutes to make my order, which was the chicken mixed combination.  I got the kifta mixed combination last time.   I received my food in less than 2 minutes! Anyways, the food was great and the rice was definitely softer this time around compared to my last visit.  The hummus, vegetable salad, pita, and falafel were exactly as I remembered!  The chicken wasn't that moist, but it was not that dry either.  If the chicken was a bit more moist, I would give this 4.5 stars (even though I can't due to integer ratings only). I still love the value and amount of food you get for $10 and nothing changed in terms of... I will definitely come back again!

Yummy food ..a place behind the jewelry store in the front. Eclectic ; people lined up all the time; like walking through a Pawn shop to get tot he restaurant; close tables, a balcony- old world charm; a kitchen that has 4-5 people busseling around that sets   high above you to order-you can feel the speed -  chop chop  and know what you want when you get to the front of the line and have your money ready- great dishes; no frills- lots of food and the yummiest falafel ever. I thought I walked into another country. Fun experience.

There are so many lunch options in the loop but this was definitely the walk from my office. This does not compare to Roti or Naf Naf grill in my opinion even though they are good. You can tell that everything is prepared fresh in front of you and they don't make too much in bulk.  It was hard to find Oasis Cafe because there is construction on Wabash so thankfully they had a sign out front. It is in the back of a jewelry store which was strange because the vendors are eyeing you like a hawk hoping that you will want to buy something on the way to lunch.  They have interesting lunch specials like kushari which most middle eastern restaurants in the loop don't serve but very yummy. I got the falafel plate which came with 6 crispy and not greasy falafel, jerusalem salad, a heap of creamy hummus and a pita for $8.11 with tax.  That is a great deal in the loop for all that food. I would of taken a picture but it was so yummy I completely blanked but I will next time which will be soon. Definitely worth a try and lots of seating.

Seriously though, what did the ownership of this restaurant need to do to for the city of Chicago to approve of walking through a jewelry store to get to this restaurant? Its so odd that it must be noted.  The restaurant will usually have a small A-frame sign outside that indicates the entrance.  You have to get to this location, before you can order food- that;s why this paragraph is necessary. The food is good, look for the daily special as that seems like a huge bang for your buck.
20 + years and still the best falafel and shwarma around.  In the back of Jewlers row. Seasoned just right, not too salty.  Treat yourself right head to the Oasis
Funky little place at the back of a jewelry market. Good enough to stay open and feed downtown workers, and not great enough to have its own location.

Gigantuous quantities for cheap (especially considering its in the Loop!). Came on a Saturday with a college friend and we both ordered Combination platters ($8.99) with chicken and their lamb/was it called kisha? meat. Topped with 3 generous falafel balls, a heaping side of hummus sprinkled with paprika, and a mound of yellow rice with huge slabs of meat, with salad and pita on the side, this dish definitely could be shared with two people.  The falafels are some of the best I've ever had. They were perfectly fried, crispy...and reminded me of fried cornbread with their hidden sweetness and texture. Their meats were a little on the dry side, but the rice underneath made up for it...plump and soft (not the dry kind of rice that I've had at other mediterranean places). Top your pita bread with hummus, some rice, and a little bit of salad and you are set - the crunchiness and lightness of the cucumbers and tomatoes will give way to the earthy tones of hummus and heaviness of the meat-flavored rice.  Yum! 4 stars because they didn't provide any yogurt sauce (not even when I asked), with it I'm sure it would've been one of the better mediterranean places I've been to (compatible to MedDeli back at UNC!). Also 4 stars because they really need a better sign...i could hardly find this place since that whole section of Wabash is filled with jewelry stores (I also felt bad walking the long trek past the eager jewelry salespeople up front all the way to the back for a $10 meal). Talk about a tease, feelsalittlebadman I'll need to come on the weekdays to try their specials!

Let's say you have $3,008 in your pocket and you have 60 minutes, and in those 60 minutes, you need to buy your wife an anniversary gift and get some lunch.  Have I got a place for you! Oasis Cafe is the Loop's hidden little gem (wait, did anyone else use that already?) that really isn't so hidden. Well, you think it's hidden because you're walking through a jewelry store to get to this secret restaurant but then you see the line of people waiting to order some falafel and you realize that Oasis Cafe is no secret. You also realize that its popularity is well deserved - great food, huge portions and inexpensive prices. Granted, the surroundings aren't exactly perfect - picture that back room where they stashed the extra tables and chairs in the restaurant you worked at in high school  - but it does the job. Just don't plan on dwelling too long after you finish eating. If you're sitting in front of an empty plate, you'll be the recipient of numerous dirty looks from downtown 9-to-5ers who want to eat their lunch and get back to work. Or back to  reddit.com . Or whatever it is they do when sitting in front of their computers.  It would be nice if everything wasn't served on or in styrofoam - I didn't even know they still made that stuff - and I think the sandwiches and entrees are better than the side dishes but you're not going to find better Medeternian fast food in the Loop.  If you really have the aforementioned three grand for an anniversary gift, I'm not sure I'd spend it on jewelry. After all, what your wife really wants is for you "pick up your stuff every once in a while and stop living like a freakin' animal." Oh wait, that's my wife.
One of my favorite lunch places downtown. I think the fact that you have to go through a jewelry store to get to it is cute and fun, although annoying for first-timers. Great food at a great price.
A diamond in the rough amongst jewelers row.  I'd rather go here than overhyped Halaal Guys.  I usually get some sort of combo and have lunch for 2 days.

Got the Morocco chicken.  It was moist and the portions were HUGE!  Pricing is fair, it was all under $10 and I couldn't finish it. Compared to other Mediterranean food it was more affordable for less money. It had a homey feel to it as everything was fresh and served in normal Styrofoam plates. Location is pretty funny since its at the back of a jewelry store - very unorthodox and different.

I was very lucky to learn about this place (thanks Yelp) while visiting Chicago. I had a Chicken and Lamb plate that also had falafel, rice, humus and pita bread. It was one of the best mediterranean food I have had in my life. The place is hidden behind a jewelry store but it is well worth finding it. Very flavorful food and good selection of beverage. There are some options for vegetarian too. I wish I had a place like this in Atlanta.

When I saw the reviews before I visited the restaurant, I had a high expectation of it, but I shocked. The food wasn't good totally. The rise and chicken kabab tested awful literally. I'm from the Middle East, so this food is from where else, but definitely not from the Middle East. Thanks!

I'm stuck with giving this place 4 stars or 5 stars. It's a great fantastic lunch spot. They give you tons of food. I always get the mixed chicken combo. Comes with rice, Jerusalem salad, 3 falafel, pita and hummus. The hummus is legit. Tastes like it's home made. But what do I know I'm Asian haha. But seriously the hummus is good. Falafel is good. I probably go here once a week. It's at the end of a long hallway of a Jewelry store. For newcomers you will be really shocked by the location. Sometimes I feel like I'm doing a walk of shame with all the Jewelry people staring at me wanting me to buy something but ignore it. Just walk with confidence all the way down to Oasis cafe! But right now I'm bitter. I'm upset. They jacked up the prices by $2. So right now I only give you 3 stars. You hurt my feelings Oasis for being greedy. =(

Yummy food. You might miss it because it's in the back of a jewelry store. It's definitely worth it. Falafel light crispy and not greasy or over cooked. Chicken shwarma seasoned and moist. Quick service

Cheap, quick, fresh and tasty food... good value for money. The place is a bit hard to find at the rear of a jewelry store and the first look doesn't give you willingness to order but passed this first impression it's all good.
Cheap, so fast, and even tastier. Perfect lunch spot and we frequent often. Falafels are great, the chicken shawarma is always super tender and never dry. One of my favorite lunch spots.

Come for the food, not the ambiance.   Solid Middle Eastern / Mediterranean food with the usual suspects:  falafel, shawarma, hummus, etc....but they also have some unique daily specials.    Tucked away in the back of a jewelry store, you're probably not expecting much as far as atmosphere goes....but Oasis Cafe can really use a make over.  The place is pretty grimy and the carpet upstairs is just plain disgusting.   All that being said, the food is absolutely delicious!  The staff is friendly and super quick, too.

Everything was tasty. I had the spinach pie combo. Service was fast and friendly. Reasonable prices and good portion sizes. Very nice, despite their quirky site beyond the jewelers' display cases off Wabash Street.
Price, flavor and serving are very good. . Highly recommend for lunch. Hard to find but worth the effort. 4 stars is what they earned.
Cheap, Fast, and Good!  Get the Mixed Combo Chicken and you'll be full for the rest of the day (maybe even have lunch for the next day). They accept Cards but prefer you bring cash.

I was very impressed with this place.  I ordered the mix combo plate with chicken and my order came out in less than 15 seconds.  My box came with a huge serving of rice, hummus, cucumber salad, 3 falafels and pita bread.  The pros were the freshness, portion size, friendly AND fast service and the flavor for everything was pretty good.  Cons: The hummus tasted a tad sweet to me and the chicken was dry.  Seasoned very well, but dry.  But for $7.50 it's easily one of the better deals in the West Loop.  I was also impressed at how large the seating area was.  Since it was at the back of a jewelry store I wasn't expecting to see so many tables.   If you're in a hurry and want something filling but don't have a lot of cash I would definitely recommend this place!

I would personally like to say that the people that work here are very friendly and the food is fresh with nice spices and will be back again and again this week while on vacation.. It is very affordable to, its actually in the back of a jewelry store in downtown Chicago. We had the lentil soup, and the special of the day " Moroccan chicken w rice, potato, tomato and cucumber.. It was a very nice portion too for Only $11.00.. You will be very pleased by going there.. See ya tomorrow! Well, been going there for lunch almost everyday while here and cAn't say enough how good this place is.. You have to try there daily specials each day except Saturday. Once again great staff, great food & reasonably priced!! What more could you want!!

I love everything about this place (especially its location) I get the lamb kabob platter every time and it has everything I could possibly want & super generous portion. The lamb has a lovely char but stays moist. Maybe the pita could be warmer but that feels like asking a lot from these guys who crank out orders super fast and up to par! Lentil soup was savory n texture on point and tabouleh is true to its name.

Great food for the price! Love the tabouleh. My husband and I shared a chicken kabob meal and ordered some stuffed grape leaves and tabouleh as well. We were both full with lots leftover! Great hole in the wall spot if you're in the city and looking for something delicious.
I like Oasis. I always get Falfafel, Hummus, and Chicken Shwarma. It is located in a jewelry store, but it is what it is.

Good Mediterranean food. Quantity is good. It's within a jewellery shop so pretty hard to locate. Not much space is a bit congested. Food is really good over here they serve you falafal for free. If you are a Mediterranean fan then you should try this one within the jewelry shop.
Today was my first time here. My friend eats here regularly. We had the falafel sandwich, which is fresh and large. Large sandwich and a drink was under $7. Check out this hidden gem.

You may need to procure some horse blinders before entering, since you'll be walking passed displays of diamonds and vintage watches before getting to your $7 lunch. The food is tasty (especially the falafels) but the portions are a little smaller than other mediterranean places (read: filling for one meal, not 1.5). I am going to end this review now before I start making bad jewel/gem puns.

I recently started working in the loop. I was looking for a place which had authentic food to go. I read the reviews on here and decided to give this place a try. Yes, it is inside a jewelry store, and yes, the line was long-ish during lunch but I feel like I was in and out in less than 10 mins. I got the Chicken Shawarma and the Lentil soup. My total was $8.84. I walked a couple blocks east to the bean and sat down at one of the benches to eat. I was pleasantly surprised by the quantity and quality of food. It was an entire bowl of delicious soup for $2.49 a super fresh sandwich. The view was spectacular too. Definitely recommend!

Oasis is one of my go-to lunch spots during the week.  It's consistently great and provides a lot of food for a reasonable price.  Although there's usually a line it moves very quick and am out the door in under 5 minutes. I'm partial to their Mixed Combo platter (chicken or kifta) but have enjoyed every dish I've tried. I highly would recommend Oasis to anyone looking to grab lunch in the Loop.
Perfect lunch spot in a quirky location. Try the Friday Special--Moroccan Couscous. Authentic, tasty, fast, and affordable.

Lord, I miss this place. I used to work right across the street, and it was difficult NOT to come here every day. The food is very reasonably priced, homemade, and for the most part, cooked to order.  Their hummus recipe should be a closely guarded secret, because it's absolutely incredible.  Make sure you get a side no matter what you order, preferably with some chewy pita to dip. The ambiance is a little quirky, but perfect for locals who lunch. I will be back very soon!!

Obvious "gem" or "diamond in the rough" pun here, but aside from that, this little known café puts places like Falafel Island and Sultan's Market to shame. Amazing Chicken Kebabs and falafel. Go here if you're down town.

A hidden jewel in a jewelry store, go figure! Random visits since late 2014/early 2015, and other than selling out of the daily specials, Oasis hasn't disappointed yet! The falafel and hummus is my favorite, haven't tasted better lentil soup anywhere else, & the Moroccan chicken is slowly taking away my taste for fried chicken. Bad day? Shawarma & Arabian coffee fixes that! Anyway, check this place out if you haven't, & buy something for someone on the way out!

The place is located insider jewelry store kinda odd place for it to be but the staff are super friendly, food is made fresh, and price is cheap for a major concern h. My lamb and hummus salad costed me less than 10 bucks including a tax. It's really w 4/5 place because location is hidden but I'll go ahead n give them 5/5 to help their ratings and business. Gotta support good quality halal food

Diamond in a rough...gem in jeweler's row....get it?!?  Lol Great place for loop lunch that serves average maybe a lil above average food. Key thing is the place does not overcharge. Yes it's in the back of a jewelry store and everyone knows about this place it's not like it's an exclusive club like atmosphere. Lol. Affordable comfort Mediterranean food. Enjoy!

Even though the hipster boat has departed this hidden gem and left all the bandwagoners behind, it still rocks my taste buds. Traveling past the jeweler to find a counter service lunch spot is an adventure every time.  Try the daily special and taste the wonders of Turkish and Arab foods. I have yet to be disappointed by the falafel here, though the rice reminds me a bit of uncle Ben's. The lunch rush is a pain Monday - Friday, although all the suits are good about cleaning their tables when they leave.

Unsurprisingly, the jewelry store stretch of Wabash is (still) under construction with scaffolding, temporary barricades, and construction vehicles everywhere obscuring the already subtle entrance to Oasis Cafe. Try looking for a sign or sample menu in the windows as you get closer to the correct door. Walk down the long aisle, past the glass displays, to a two-level seating area with plenty of larger tables for a group lunch.  Despite the distance from my office in the south end of the Loop, I think Oasis Cafe is the better of the Middle Eastern non-chain lunch joints. Compared to Falafel Island, its portions are still big enough for two meals albeit a little smaller and therefore, cheaper. The meat was tender and well-seasoned, the hummus was fresh and delicious, and the falafel was crunchy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. They also offer a daily special to keep things interesting and my friend has praised their lentil soup. My only critique is that the Shish Kabob combo promised baba ganoush but I was given hummus instead - the hummus was great, but I wanted baba ganoush!

Just OK. If you're in the area and craving Mediterranean food, this is your spot. However, I would never go out of my way for it either. The food was decent, very affordable and it's kind of fun that it's in the back of a jewelry store. Nothing about my meal particularly stood out though.

I came here thinking I'd get a gem with all the yelp reviews I saw, but honestly it was just OK. I wasn't really impressed. Prices were friendly bc almost everything was under $10 and the food was ready in good time, but I didn't think the food tasted as good as other places I've been. Portions are pretty big for what you pay. Maybe there are certain dishes that are really good, and maybe I just got an OK dish.  A big downer - I had taken my nephew, and he got sick from the food. He puked it all up like 6 hours later. Location: It's hidden behind a jewelry shop as well. A few blocks away from Millennium park. It definitely feels authentic, but I'm no expert. I do think here are other places that taste better though.

When people say its a hidden gem, they aren't kidding! Its in the back of a jewelry store. However, it is great food with great prices. It is always busy at lunch but the staff their moves very fast. Highly recommend!

Who doesn't enjoy a little falafel with they're jewelry purchases?!  Ok, so I don't exactly have jewelry money, but I do have falafel money.  Sometimes they'll even give you free samples of that while you're walking down the street, so that's so much the better.  Really I like to come over here for the Tuesday Moroccan chicken special.  You get enough food for two meals and the service is quick, quick, quick.  I always do takeout but there are a few tables if you're interested in hiding out instead of heading back to the office.  I usually grab an order of hummus as well and get two lunches for around $11 and not even a block away from work.  Not a bad plan if you ask me.  They're not even cash only!

Just ate here.  Funny little place tucked into a jewelry store.  Do not let that deter you!  Veggie plate was great!  My husband loved the falafel.  All things on it too.   I got the lamb kabob sandwich and my husband got ck shwarma.  Just perfect!

Affordable, fast, and tasty. Oasis is a great place to go if you're looking for a lunch stop in the loop. For less than 10 dollars, you can get enough amazing food for two small meals as a light eater. Properly cooked, plated with a heavy hand, and a fun adventure to find, Oasis shines as part of my weekend in Chicago. We plan on returning soon.
A hidden gem with some of the best Middle Eastern food in the Loop. The chicken shawarma is amazing and I believe most of their food is scratch made.

First of all - this place is literally in the back of a jewelry store. How weird is that?  Secondly - the food was good, it was cheap and the service was lightning fast. I literally didn't believe the food was mine because it appeared so quickly. I had the chicken shawarma sandwich, and I thought it was really, really good! The pita was very fresh.

Location- back of a jewelry store...that story alone is worth the trip. Great lunch spot that has been on the weekly rotation ever since discovering this place (thanks Yelp). Seems like everyone has their favorite special day...the Moroccan chicken is the best. Loads of food for a very reasonable price and I've never had trouble finding a table if I'm eating with colleagues. Highly recommend for anyone working in the loop whose looking for a new lunch spot.  Note: They take cards, but prefer cash, and since everyone there is so welcoming and friendly hit up the ATM on the way.

Visiting Chicago and looking for a reasonably priced place to eat downtown. You have to hunt a little to find Oasis, but it's worth the trouble both on flavor and price! The Friday special is Moroccan Couscous, which I added beef to. The vegetables and couscous are terrifically flavorful. The kafta adds a nice heartiness. I added baklava and Turkish coffee and the total bill is barely $12. A bargain and a great place to suss out.
This is a perfect casual lunch spot. Weirdly you enter through a jewelry store, but the food is legit.  The hummus is top-notch, and the lamb was grilled perfectly. The falafels are also excellent.

Walking in here, even having read the reviews, I was still struck by the experience of walking into a jewelry store and ending up in a cafe.  I had the dark meat chicken mixed plate which was lovely and juicy, with great creamy hummus and a perfectly crisp and light falafel.
You can't beat this place, nor the experience of traversing through the jewerly exchange to get delicious high quality food, quickly made at a cheap price with courteous people. What's not to love?

First, the pita: Doughy, chewy, dry, not good. I should have learned from the first time I went here and they messed up my order. Second time around I ordered a staple, chicken schwarma, and it ranks last on my schwarma list. Tahini should be included with each order of this, it wasn't. Just a big plate of rice and some chicken with 2 cucumbers. It might not be family owned, but if you want good schwarma, Naf Naf is where its at.

I used to come in here often and the food was amazing, lines went fast, and there was often seating.  Today there wasn't a line today so it moved fast and there was no one in there eating.  The guy taking orders at the register was unfriendly and the falafel sandwich I got today was cold, missing sauce, and the cucumbers were bitter.  I probably won't come back again after today's visit.  My companion's sandwich (chicken) was also not very good he said and it was his first time here.  Something happened in the last 30 days and I'm really curious why the decline in quality!

This place is awesome. Not only is it in a freakin jewelry store, but the food is super authentic and high quality. There are a lot of options on the menu, the portions are quite large, and there is basically no wait at all. I had the Mixed Plate which came with falafel, hummus, salad, rice, chicken kabob, and pita. It was all great and I definitely couldn't finish everything. I tried a bit of the kefta as well, which was cooked very well. I went around noon and the place was jam packed with people waiting for tables. That was only surprising because I just didn't realize so many people were aware of this place. I will certainly be coming back.

I go to school nearby and wanted something other than a chain to get a quick cheap bite at. I came across this place on Yelp and was determined to find it. So worth it! Falafel sandwich was perfect! Will definitely go back again!

Their chicken shawarma is so good, melts in your mouth.Full of flavor with the perfect amount of spice.The falafel and Hummus is awesome as well.I'm getting hungry just talking about it. They definitely give you a run for your money.One of the best in the city.
Food: Very few options (mainly falafel was only thing available), average taste Service: Average Ambiance: not good at all

This place is a hidden gem - no pun intended. Ok. Pun intended. Although based on the number of people waiting in line, they might need a better hiding spot.  I recently started working in the city again and tend to wander until I find something that catches my eye. Today I wanted to get off my normal route, so I turned to Yelp to find a place close to the office, but somewhere I hadn't been. Enter Oasis Cafe.  I had the Chicken Shawarma Plate, which is my default meal when trying a new Mediterranean restaurant. I'm not a big falafel eater - although I was super tempted seeing them here. Next visit - which will probably be tomorrow.  Back to the shawarma...you're given the choice of rice or hummus as a side. I opted for the hummus which was extremely creamy and certainly one of the best I've had. The shawarma was perfect. It wasn't overly seasoned, but not bland. It was cooked to perfection - a nice mix of crunchy charred bits with tender chicken. It wasn't dry. It wasn't greasy. It was...just right.  Included with the plate was pita. My favorite pita is across the street at Naf-Naf, mostly because it's pillowy and still warm from the oven. The pita at Oasis was very good and rivals that of Naf-Naf.  This is my new destination for Mediterranean food in the Loop.

Inconspicuously tucked behind a jewelry store, Oasis is probably the best Mediterranean food I've had in Chicago.  I recommend the Moroccan chicken, which comes with warm, tender, flavorful chicken over a bed of rice and a side of well-cooked potatoes.  The meal as a whole is very filling and an enjoyable eat.

This is my favorite secret Chicago lunch. They have the best falafel I've ever had outside of Israel, which is an annoying pretentious thing to say but who cares, it's true. The food is super fast, their entrees are enormous, and again, I can't say it enough, their falafel sandwich is KILLER.  Plus, it's in the back of a jewelry store, so you get to look at diamonds on your way in. One star off bc it's really a lunch place for people who work in the city, and never seems to be open when I am downtown on weekends or evenings.

The Wednesday special stuffed chicken is delicious and is a lot of food for a good price. There's also additional seating upstairs, so you can get a table throughout lunch which is really nice during the lunch hour rush in the Loop.
Excellent food tucked in a jewelry shop...yup. Great value too. Outstanding hummus. Chicken shawarma sand was highlight, esp for under $6

This place is unreal. I come here every Wednesday religiously for their Wednesday special - Napole Stuffed Chicken Breast. The quality of the food is always consistent: the chicken is juicy and tender, the stuffed spinach, cucumber and tomato give a nice fresh balance to the taste. You can have a choice of rice, salad, lettuce or a mixed of those. The people work there are friendly, helpful and efficient. All of the above makes it the best Wednesday lunch spot in the city! Did I mention they also have the best falafel in the whole universe? My boyfriend will always order extra falafels with his stuffed chicken.

Great food meat a little dry but it is still good a cool little hole in the wall. Have to walk into Jewler then in the back is this cool little Mediterranean place. The feel is ok but over all is a great place to eat

Oasis Cafe is a wednesday tradition for us. Located in the back of a jewelry store on wabash, this hidden gem's name is completely fitting. The Napole stuffed chicken never disappoints and keeps me coming back week after week. It's always tender, juicy, and flavorful served over rice or salad. I tend to order a mix of salad/rice and both sauces with a couple falafels on top.  Do yourself a favor and try the wednesday special. I'm certain you'll soon join us as regulars to this delicious establishment!
Fantastic Middle Eastern cafe in the back of a jewellery store - you'd never know it was there. Great, authentic food, very reasonably priced. A hidden gem (see what I did there?)

They definitely have the best falafel. I have also tried their lamb plate that comes with falafel and hummus. I think they have the most authentic hummus ever! They also have yummy and healthy soups which are only 2.76$ with tax and that's a steal deal. My favorite is the lentil soup that they have daily, they also have special soups everyday.  I brought many of my friends and family here and everyone loved the food.

I was really impressed by the reviews.. But when I landed there found to be one of the worst Mediterranean food I had ever had.. The food isn't fresh. The chicken shawarma isn't actually shawarma.. Neither the hummus is good.. Waste of time.. Avoid the cafe..
Affordable ethnic food hidden behind a jewelry store.  But don't get thrown off.  This is a great place for the money and if you like middle eastern food!

The kebab combo platter was flavorful and had huge portions. They had great falafel, babaganouj, lamb, rice, hummus, and pita. And while I wish the pita was served warmer and more fluffy, there is really not much to complain about. I'm a fan.  To access this restaurant, you have to pass through a diamond store. So if you're ever in the mood to blow money on jewelry immediately after a filling but not disgusting lunch, this might be the perfect place for you!  The kebabs are very flavorful, but where Oasis Cafe really stands out is the hummus, which is fresh, flavorful, and lovely. I'm typically not a fan of the hummus, but it made everything better.  Try it!

I've eaten a lot of mediterranean food in my life and this just wasn't that good. I order the veggie platter special and was disappointed with most of the items. The salad of cucumbers and tomatoes was a little bland and could have used a little lemon. The bead was thick and cold. The grape-leaves weren't fully cooked as they couldn't hold all the ingredients. The falafel was pretty bland and also really cold. The highlights were the hummous and baba gannoush, which were done well. Maybe I'd give this place another try and order meats but the veggies are sub-par.

Why does "oasis" always mean "amazing falafel?" This hidden gem inside the jewelry mall maze along Wabash is beyond amazing. The falafel rules. Sandwich or the dinner with tahini rice. Chicken swarma, lamb, whatever. And the price is beyond right. So cheap and so good. Always a go-to.
Bumping this back up to a 4 because you can eat a delicious chicken tabouleh salad AND buy a necklace for your mistress in one trip. Wish they had a shoe shine.

Hidden literally inside a jewelry store!! Just walk in and head straight to the back. I had the Friday Couscous special with lamb and it was super good! Good for small groups of about four or five each.

Good medditreanian food for lunch. Service is quick.  A little unusual that its in the back of a jewerly store.  Had the kefa kabab plate.  Everything was good. Nothing great but good for a quick lunch.  Was $10 with a soda.
The meat was very good but the rice was very bland and their spicy sauce has no flavor at all.
It's a hidden gem of a fast restaurant.  Hard to find but well worth it.  Just look for jewelry mart and keep walking in

The taste of the food was unexpectedly good for a place that you wouldn't think that their employees were professionally trained in cooking school. The price was also cheap, while the portion of each menu we had was gigantic. We left the place with a full stomach and smile face. Little did we know the evening after we had this for lunch, my boyfriend had stomach problem and that food was the only thing we had that day. The meat/chicken may not have been the freshest, even if it was prepared/cooked well.

This place blew me away both price-wise and taste-wise. Not only was the food extremely affordable (everything on the menu is less than $10! Check out the menu on their website though. The one on yelp is outdated), it was also probably the best thing I've put in my mouth all year. I got a chicken shwarma sandwich and the meat was so perfectly seasoned I didn't know what to do with myself. It was also perfectly complemented by fresh diced cucumber, parsley, tomato and cabbage.  I also love the location. It's in the back of a jewelry store! Took me a couple of tries to find it - it was quite literally a hidden gem. Very highly recommend! Looking forward to returning soon and often!
LOVED this place. Not much on ambience, but delicious food, generous proportions, reasonably priced, and quick service. I am definitely coming back.
It was very quiet when we were at the restaurant. The food was amazing, my friend was amazed. The prices were also very good. This is going to be my favorite Middle Eastern food spot in downtown now.

My group of friends and I went to Oasis to get lunch on the Saturday during St. Patty's Day weekend and sadly, they were out of rice and lamb, which are the two main ingredients for Mediterranean food. A few of my friends were a little drunk so we were really hungry and the only option was pretty much salad... So we left to another place and did not even get to try it. I was so disappointed.

This is a nice little "hidden" gem--it really is hard to find if you're not looking for it, but enough people know about it now that it's not truly "hidden". It fills up very fast. Their stuff is solid, not the best that I've had but a nice place to have a meal.

If you're looking for cheap, heavy, flavorful Mediterranean food that will be assembled and ready for you before you even have time to sign off on the receipt, Oasis is the place for you. A great lunch spot with very generous portions. For a sampling of the best of Oasis, go with the kebab combo platter ($9) which is chunks of beef or lamb shish with three falafel, babaganouj, and rice. I always opt for the lamb shish, which is plentiful and pleasantly charred. The falafel are consistently great, crispy (but not oily) on the outside and warm and fluffy on the inside. Babaganouj is some of the best you can find in the Loop. Chunky, smoky, and creamy, this is eggplant at its best, not the mushy, applesauce-texture stuff that babaganouj sometimes ends up being.  Their hummus is extremely rich and flavorful, heavy on the tahini. I've had the very popular Wabash special, but found that I enjoyed the fluffy falafel, heavy hummus, and earthy foul more than the actual chicken pasilla, which was decent, just not very memorable. The Moroccan chicken was very tender and juicy, but didn't pack the same flavor that I'm used to from Oasis. Kofta are also delicious, but relatively standard.  The one big disappointment is their pita, which is pre-baked, flat, and cold by the time it's served to you in individual plastic wraps. My recommendation: skip the chicken and the pita sandwiches, there are better places in the Loop for that (I'm looking at you, Naf Naf.) Instead, go for some combination of the flavorful shish kebabs and falafel with the outstanding babaganouj and hummus on the side.

If you want authentic middle eastern food , this is the place !  Everything taste good . My favorite is the chicken shawarma .  The only thing I don't like is that special of the day tends to run out really early during the day ! :-( . Other than that this place is really good !!!

You get good food fast at a reasonable price. Isn't that what we're all looking for? There's a small sign outside of the jewelry store and in the back is the café, there's plenty of seating including some tables upstairs. They move really quick, if you are in a rush then go vegetarian or opt for the chicken (beef and lamb take longer). They do take credit cards. Very friendly staff.

This is a good place to grab a tasty falafel and lentil soup. Enter through the jewelry store on Wabash, and check out the diamond cutters hard at work along the way to the back of the building. Inexpensive, quick and relatively healthy food including vegetarian offerings for about $7-9 a meal (excluding beverages) and seating is available.
Thanks to yelp! I got to experience this place for the 1st time. Its hidden away behind a jewelry store. We ordered a Monday's Special. .it sure was special..it was delicious n fast service.

So I ordered the Friday special - Moroccan couscous which comes with steamed carrots, cauliflower,  spinach, zucchini,  potatoes, eggplant. I also ordered with chicken, plus a drink - $9 and change. The dish also comes with a side of pita. The couscous was very dry and bland. Couscous should be light and airy. The steamed vegetables were way overcooked and again bland, essentially mush. It truly was criminal how overcooked those veggies were. The chicken was sliced paper thin but had good flavor. Not only did the dish lack flavor but there was hardly any sauce. Give me a side of tahini atleast. The serving is fairly large but not worth the $8 bucks.  There are so many Mediterranean spots to choose from in the Loop, won't be back.

Best Baba Ganouj in the loop! Seriously I'm in love, it's perfect with its tender morsels of smoky eggplant chunks interspersed between creaminess. The eggplant pieces fall apart in your mouth and the overall sauce is perfectly balanced with sumac spice, lemon and garlic. I would order it by the bucket to take home if they offered.  We ordered a veggie plate, cup of soup of the day and falafel sandwich. Which ended up being more than necessary for two people because the portion sizes were generous. The falafel was certainly fresh and had a great crispy exterior and moist interior. Overall, the quality was extremely high. Our only disappointment was the pita isn't fresh (as in made throughout the day). The soup of the day, some kind of vegetable, rice and garbanzo bean concoction, was very "homey" and simple in a delicious way.  Very good if you are looking for some healthy, home style comfort food.  The interior of the restaurant is purely functional but plentiful. The situation within the jewelry store is.... interesting.... Awkward at first but the you can people watc
tuesday special: moroccan chicken.  chicken. that. falls. off. the. bone.  'nuff said.

A hidden gem! Literally, hidden! You wouldn't even notice it's there unless you're on the hunt for it. Oasis Cafe is actually located BEHIND a Jewelry shop - meaning you actually walk through the jewelry shop to get to the restaurant in the back. My family and I were looking for a quick bite to eat and decided on Oasis Cafe and couldn't figure out where it is until we saw a small sign outside the jewelry shop.  Food - Cheap and tons! I was there with 7 adults and 4 children and the food was fantastic. For the prices, you receive a lot of food and out total was about $60 which isn't bad considering the amount of people it fed, and there was a lot left over to take home. It really felt like authentic Mediterranean cuisine and I would definitely recommend the Falafel Platter and the Hummus.  If I come back to Chicago again, I might try this place again. Chicago is such a foodie city and tons of restaurants to try, which is why I say "might". But yes, definitely a great place for cheap, good, and large portioned Mediterranean cuisine!

This is indeed a tiny oasis inside a jewelry store. Thanks to Yelp, I managed to find this place, if not I would never have discovered this little gem. I was searching for a lunch spot that was cheap, quick and delicious. Oasis cafe was the answer.  I had the chicken shawarma plate with pita and some hummus. It was delicious. I'm sure everything else on the menu is good too!

If you take it for what it is, this is a four star establishment.  It is a great place for a solidly executed, quick option for the lunch crowd.  A cafeteria sort of setting in the back of a jeweler, the menu is highlighted by daily specials.  I am a fan of the Thursday special, Wabash mixed combo. The combo comes with beans, hummus, a small salad and three falafel balls with pita.  The star of the show is a large phyllo burrito stuffed with diced Moroccan spiced chicken and vegetables.  The chicken is packed with aromatic spices and moist.  The hummus creamy and flavorful. I think its worth the stop for a 15 min lunch.

Gem of a place.  Had the falafel sandwich.  Simple but good Perfect lunch stop.  Fast and healthy.  Why are things that are worth the trip found in holes in the wall joints?  I thought it was cool that it was in the back of a jewelry store.  If I wasn't embarrassed I would have went for another sandwich.

Don't expect anything to wow you at Oasis Grill, but do expect a good meal with monstrous portions and ultra quick service.  Some items are better than others.  In my view, the dark meat chicken is by far the tastiest option.  Plates run for about $8 and sandwiches for $5.  Plates include a side of rice, hummus, fattoush (tomato, cucumber, parsley) and pita.  The dark meat plate usually comes with grilled veggies in lieu of the fattoush.  As what others have noted, the rice doesn't have a whole lot of flavor, but the hummus and fattoush are really good.  The chicken shawarma from the spit is pretty good as long as you eat it while it's fresh.  The kefta, the few times I've ordered it, really lacks flavor.  Depth of the seasonings in all items is missing, and I suspect this is to appeal to the Western palate.   I've tried pretty much all the other options in the area (Naf Naf and Rotti), and I find Oasis to be the best of the bunch in taste and value.  Oasis is definitely worth a visit if you work or are visiting the loop area!

Had lunch at Oasis today. It was basically the same as many of the falafel places in the loop. The seating area and all aren't as nice as one of the small chain type places that have popped up over the past few years. It's a hidden place in the middle of the Diamond Mall. The tables/chairs and all aren't that great. The service is super-fast - I think they basically have everything ready-to-go and they just quickly throw it together and serve it. It was basically like pay and pick-up - with ZERO wait-time. Food-wise, I liked my falafel sandwich and the hummus side was also good. Those two things ran me $10, which is the norm in the area. Nothing really stood out to me... it was all decent. I would go back to Oasis if I was in the area and wanted falafel.

I came to Oasis on a friend's recommendation. The novelty of a middle eastern cafe in the back of a jewelry store/bazaar sounded like an experience to be had. I arrived just before the lunchtime rush, at 11:30 a.m., and there were just 2 people ahead of me in line. The cafe has ample seating, except that its popular and the seating becomes scarce at 12:30. You'll be rubbing elbows with workers in the area. Not exactly a tourist hot spot.  I ordered the chicken shawarma plate, and it came with yellow rice, hummus, pita bread, slices of tomatoes and cucumber, and chicken shawarma. There was a good-sized portion of all these items, but in terms of food quality, "meh, I have experienced better." Thus, my 2-star rating. I've been spoiled with the likes of Ollie's in Dearborn, MI, and even better, Haifa Falafel in Ypsilanti, MI. The food at Oasis is spiced down for the clientele in downtown. The yellow rice is just that: yellow. Nothing special. The chicken is well-cooked and not rubbery, but its near tasteless. The food is lukewarm at best, and my food arrived cold.  Overall, this is a place for a quick lunch in a convenient location. Its definitely made for the Midwestern palate.

I lost interest in my sandwich half-way through.  The eggplant was not seasoned well, the tomatoes were hard and unripe, the veggies were barely chopped and didn't really fit in the sandwich, and they only serve plain pita--no whole wheat, what gives?  Plus the lighting is too bright and all the pictures on the wall are hanging at 45-degree angles. This place is resting on its laurels.
Every time I go the food is great and fresh, go early tho lines get pretty long but it goes fast which is great for everyone

Freaky fast Middle Eastern food and the falafel are to very crisp and tasty too! Definitely come back when I get the craving. It's not really big on overall look but the overall food is something really nice.

I was unimpressed with my meal here.  The only thing that is really standout is the hummus which I will label the best I have ever eaten.  The pita bread is sad stuff and the lamb was neither exceptionally tasty or tender.  I can get a much more satisfying meal at Roti.

So my only meal before coming here was breakfast the morning of the day BEFORE. By lunch, I was starving so i turned to my trusty yelp app as I was caving some kind of middle eastern food. I thought about Roti, but wanted something closer to my office.  I found Oasis Cafe. Big mistake. I got a Wabash special or whatever their thursday special was. The only thing that was really good was the hummus on the side. Well, I skipped dinner that night because I simply wasn't hungry, and woke up with my whole body aching. I thought it was weird because otherwise I felt fine. ..fast forward two hours and I was at work with a fever. I came home and went straight to the bathroom. I had food poisoning. Violent food poisoning. Given this was the only thing I ate for maybe 50 hours, it doesn't take a genius to figure it out. ...needless to say, I won't be returning Shame - their prices were reasonable

Best middle eastern downtown, quick, tasty, moderately priced. An amazing place for lunch. The pita sandwiches are always solid, but I'm a bigger fan of the plates. The daily special is always good for lunch, and there's almost always enough left for dinner.

Hidden local gem in the loop being located in a jewelry store.   Quality authentic middle eastern food at a reasonable price for the portion received.    The food was served fast, fresh and hot.   They have a seating area that wasn't too crowded at 1230 on a Wednesday as it appeared most did carry out.     The beef Shish kabob plate was delish especially the hummus, which is one of the better ones i have had at a restaurant.

Worth looking for. In the back of a jewelry mall the lab couscous was delicious and the felafel was among the best I've had and perfectly crispy. I usually find kefta a bit dull, but here it was perfectly spiced and wonderful An outstanding value for lunch

(truly) hidden gem you have to "know" about to go to.  they were one of the original shawerma restaurants way back before it became trendy, and they're still great with a loyal following.  the difference between oasis and the competition is that Oasis is very personal and not a "shawerma factory".

I met a friend for lunch at Oasis Cafe a few weeks ago.  I had the shish kebab sandwich and it was wonderfully juicy and flavorful.   Part of the appeal of the place for me is that you have to find it by walking through a jewelry store.  I got there at 11:30AM and didn't have to wait to order, but by noon, there was quite a line.  Apparently, the secret is out (200+ reviews on Yelp is another strong indicator that I'm not the first to discover this place). A small complaint would be that some of the menu items require real silverware rather than plastic to completely enjoy. Try Oasis Cafe for lunch if you're in the Loop, but I recommend getting there early.

Truly a hidden gem within a jewelry mart. Definitely not known to tourist. You know you've struck gold when locals and mostly muddle eastern clients lest here. Ordered the falafel sandwich and hubby ordered a chicken kebab. The hummus was NOT gritty!!! Smooth as butter.  The place is small but the portions are big and delicious. If we had a bigger appetite, we would have ordered lentil soup. Pure bliss. Will be back.

This is my first time going there and it was just OK. Since I've moved here I've been looking for an awesome middle eastern deli but sadly this was not it. The food is good if you're just looking to stay in the healthy diet arena but not fantastic. Also, everyone reviewed and said the food was averaged a $4 however the faleel sandwich was $4.49+tax and everything else is between $6-8 bucks. I might go back again to try the chicken but for the faleel, I like mine a bit spicy.
It's located in the back of a jewelry store, but don't let that deter you. This is a must try!

I remember when I was a kid and there were a few mom and pop places in the Loop. They are mainly gone. That is sad as you know what you are getting at Jmmy John's, but it means a lack of diversity in food. I mean how can there be that many Subways in the Loop?  That said, this has become my favorite place to eat in the Loop. I mean I love this place! I have never had anything that I did not like.  I am very big on the Shish ka bab sandwich now. I prefer the lamb. It is not made in advance, there is about a 7 minute wait. Isn't it great to wait for something that is being made and not microwaved! Okay, I have had it with the tomatoes and cucumbers which is great, but one day they put roasted peppers on it and it was just incredible! I just noticed they have sugar free Baclava, can that even exist? Seriously, it's less than eating at the wretched Panda Express or Mc Donalds and I suspect this may even be healthy!

I got my plate the second my dropped the order- wtf o.O  Fast, inexpensive, healthy, mediocre lunch. Took me a while to find the place tho. It's opposite American glasses shop, with a tiny street sign saying oasis cafe in the jewelry shop.

I've been lunching at Oasis for at least 10 years and absolutely nothing has changed - which is great. The falafel sandwich is the still the best you can get in the Loop, the line moves quick and you get your food super fast. What more can you want?

Easy to miss if you're not familiar with the area (you have to walk through a jeweler a shop) but this place is very quick, reasonably priced and has a decent menu. I had the mixed grill with chicken. Everything was pretty tasty - well seasoned chicken, good rice and very tasty hummus. Two large pitas were a nice bonus. I got here around 11:30 And beat the lunch rush as people started streaming in by quarter to 12.

Yikes, another place with super mediocre med. food in the loop. BUT it's cheap, very fast, and nested in a diamond shop just in case you want to pick up your significant other something over your lunch break. If you're in the loop for lunch, yeah maybe, but not much point for this place otherwise.

DELICIOUS, AUTHENTIC FOOD. Very refreshing to eat at a restaurant like this (not a boring, corporate sandwich/soup/salad place) in the loop. The guys behind the counter are always nice and helpful. Also, the servings are awesomely huge :)

This is pretty crazy and I love taking others here for the response.  Going to a middle eastern joint in the back of a jewelry store is not expected, but warmly welcomed after you eat here. Love the kabobs, shawarma, hummus and pita bread here.  You get a good portion for the money.  No frills.  Just food.  Fast service.  Quick eats. Do go expecting anything but really good Middle Eastern food at a really good price for the loop.

This place is Money Balls good.  Walk past a couple of jewelry shops, pick up a Jesus piece, maybe a new watch battery, before you get to the back where Oasis lies.  Give me my shawarma plate with double rice, pita, hummus and veggies, and don't forgot the hot sauce.  Just get ready to find a couch back at the office to nap afterwards.
Definitely a hidden gem. Unexpected find at the back of a jewelry store but I'm glad we persevered and ordered. Highly recommend. Come hungry - big plates.

If you work in the loop, you should put Oasis on your list of places to experience at least once. You can't beat the ambiance of Mediterranean/Middle Eastern cuisine in the back of a jewelry store. There was plenty of seating even during the lunch rush, and our food came out nearly immediately.  The line was fast too. We could have gotten in and out in just 5 minutes, but instead we decided to eat and watch people shop for rings, necklaces, and expensive watches. I wonder if it cheapens the jewelry shopping experience when you have people feeding their face and watching you peruse gold and silver encased whatevers. The food, however, was less than memorable. I got the daily special, a Moroccan spiced chicken and rice plate with sides of hummus and some falafel. Big portions but bland flavors.  There are a lot of Mediterranean options in the loop, and while Oasis had the unusual jewels and falafel bedfellows that got me through the door, I'll go elsewhere for more flavorful stuff in the future - unless, of course, my appetite draws me in for those huge portions again.
Not bad. The chicken schwarma was good enough but lacked the kind of pizzazz I've come to enjoy in middle eastern food. It mostly just tasted like curry. The prices are great for Chicago, though!

I love this place.  I'm here at least once a week.  For price, speed, and quality they can't be matched. The falafel is always fresh and the chicken shawarma is tender and juicy. And I love that it's nestled back behind jewelry store.  I always feel like I'm going to a secret restaurant that only the locals know about.

I stumbled upon this place thanks to Yelp and I'm so glad I did. It's kind of an odd place for a restaurant - the place is tucked away in the back of a jewelry store - but the food is awesome. I highly recommend the falafel and hummus!

It's really hidden behind two jewelry stores but once you get there it's actually really nice. Clean place, good food and affordable price. I couldn't have asked for more after hours of walking and sightseeing!

The shawerma was a soggy mess. I ate it there so it's not like the tahini sauce sat there in a to go order. The sauce was thin and runny and everything was drenched in it.  The side of tahini they give you in the little cup was much thicker. They only offer chicken shawerma and its white meat chicken so it's a little dryer and less flavorful.   If you're craving shawerma like I was this isn't your fix.

Used to be my regular Friday lunch when i worked in the Loop. Its in a nice jewellery store and an added bonus for womenfolk like me who obsess over jewels. The food is always good and they maintain the standards. I enjoy grabbing a bite ,especially the chicken shwarma or combo platter whenever i am in the neighborhood.

Have you been here? Do you know where this place is? Because it's amazing. Seriously. Freakin'. Amazing.  This LITERALLY hidden gem is tucked away inside one of the jewelry stores on Jeweler's Row. Truly an Oasis of JOY. Nothing fancy, just some fast cheap and easy Mediterranean food. Wait in line for a minute, place your order, get your food, sit in their caf-like seating area or take it to-go. Either way, it's delish. Pita. Baba. Hummus. Falafel. Baklava. Daily specials. Freaky fast, just like Jimmy John's... If you haven't been...get your ass over there.  I haven't had anything here that I didn't absolutely love.
Lightning fast falafel during lunch hours and good baba

The puns are too easy here. A "gem," the "crown jewel," or a "diamond in the rough" -- Oasis Cafe is in the back of a jewelry store like Alando is in the back of a coffee shop in Bethlehem, PA and is as inconspicuous as El Rincon Del Sabor in NYC's jewelry district. In fact, if the folding sign isn't up on the sidewalk, I'm not sure how you'll find this place. This was the fastest I had ever been served in my life, anywhere -- except, for maybe picking an apple from a tree. I asked the cashier which was the better among the kafta or the lamb; to which, she advised the lamb because the kafta would take a little longer. I had some time but went with the recommendation and ordered the Morrocan couscous special with lamb. 1.7 seconds after the cashier swiped my credit card, a dish appeared on the counter in front of me like it had fallen from the heavens above. It may have bounced -- I don't recall. It was too fast for me to realize what had just happened. "Is that mine?" I asked with confusion. "You," said the presumable line cook. "Are you kidding? When did you cook this?" "It's yours." I don't know how they did it and I don't ask those questions before I'm about to eat. But, it was great and I'd go back if I'm up for a quick, quiet meal. The only thing to avoid is the jewelry.
Everything here is delicious and comes in ridiculously large servings for usually less than $9. Its a grad student's dream.

This is one of those places I always seem to forget about -- in part because it is somewhat hidden. Oasis Café is located in the rear of a jewelry store. That's right. You could very easily walk past and not even notice. However, should you pass and miss it, you are truly missing out.  The food is fast, delicious (specifically, the kefta kebob plate or the vegetarian combo), and inexpensive. The portion size is big too! I always seem to finish only about a third of my meal while I am there. The line can get long (but moves quickly) and there is plenty of seating!
Tasty Mediterranean hidden gem in the Loop. A work lunch takeout standby in the Financial District. Fresh shwarma, falafel and hummus. Cheap pricing.

This tucked in deli serves Reasonably authentic middle eastern fast fare.  Some things taste better than others but overall is good.  Great Arabic/Turkish coffee is also on the menu .  You may run into an occasional celebrity.

I go here regularly and order the hummus appetizer. It comes with 2 pitas and I usually order a couple of more (they're like. 25 apiece for additional ones.) It's tasty.  I've had the spinach pie a couple of times but it is oddly seasoned and has an overwhelming bitter lemony taste, so you're best off to avoid that.
Fast, yummy, Mediterranean food! Falafel=excellent!
Believe that I've gotten sick off the Tabouleh twice, second time severely, so I won't be going back.  I worry about cross-contamination when they're chopping meat & vegetables.

This is a fine Middle Eastern joint run by a couple of fine Mexican brothas amidst some jewelry stores run by a fine desi brotha with his pants rolled up above his ankles, and some other random ethnos.  Eating Middle Eastern cuisine while listening to Cumbia in the background, sippin on a diet coke can! Could I be any happier?! Additionally, the fine Mexican brotha who took mah order, let's call him Gerard, offered me up a sampler plate of kefta kabob in addition to my ample order of the Wabash combo special, definitely enough food to squeeze out another meal! I'd definitely stop by here again!

Ever since giving up a steady diet of falafel and kebab wraps whilst in Copenhagen a few years ago, I have been looking for some place to fill that void stateside. Spoiler alert: there is no replacing that delicious, greasy mess. However, Oasis has gotten the closest yet. Sure, they're bizarrely located, but it works. The falafel is crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside. Just the right ratio of veggies, falafel and sauce. The lunch time line will be out the door, but it's not a long wait. And that's when items are usually at the freshest. Whenever I've dropped by later in the day, they either freshly prepare my order or they grab a lukewarm leftover from the lunch rush. Still tasty, just not living up to its full awesome potential.

This was a good dining experience.  It's in a weird space, but the nice thing is that it's not frenetic like many of the other mediterranian places in the loop are.  They mostly have all adopted this "Chipotle" approach of small space, barely any place to sit, assembly line approach.  Oasis is more of a "deli counter" approach and they have a larger than expected area to sit in without someone standing over you, on you, etc.   The food was good.  It's not "to die for" and it's not bad by any means.  It was just good, solid, tasty food.  Just what you would expect and want.  The staff aren't putting on a fake happy smile and over-the-top approach.  They're there to take your order make the food.  It's quick and it's good. Would I go back?  Yes.  Would I recommend this place to others?  Yes.
Need to get your pinky ring cleaned and have a falafel while you wait? This place has got you. It was good but not THAT good, or cheap. I would say A-OK.

Make your way back through the jewelers to enjoy yummy baba ganouj, hummus, falafel, and Jerusalem salad. And very courteous service from the staff. One criticism: several tables were not cleaned /bused.

Easy to find. Just walk up Wabash and you will see the sign. The good here is really good and reasonably priced. I had the hummus appetizer (about $4) and the felafel sandwich (about $5), and they were both very good. I also tried the grape leaves, which were a disappointment (I would skip them next time). The baklava was also very good. Nothing jumped out at me as incredible, but a good solid meal, perfect for lunch. There is plenty of seating here. I counted about 30 spots downstairs, and there might have been another 20 up. I got there about 130ish and it was not crowded. More people got to-go while I was there than sat down. If you are in a hurry, this is the place for you. It takes more time to walk through the jewelry store than it does to order, pay and get your food. If you are close and looking for lunch, this would be a good place to try.

Was wondering aimlessly looking for something to eat in the loop, accidentally glanced down and saw sign for Mediterranean food and the first thing that popped in my mind was "falafel" and my mind was made up to go to this place. It was weird for a second that I had to walk thru a few jewelry stands to get to the Oasis.  The menu which seems like a hundred items listed and pictures, plastered along the drink refrigerators - It was overwhelming for a moment but I had a taste for lamb and just scanned the menu for those four letters.  It was a good choice, I got a sampling platter with lamb morsels on top of yellow rice, the meal included a warm pita, four crispy falafel and a heaping of hummus. All this delicious food for under $10.  It was so good, I literally licked the plate clean and wanted more. The Oasis is a hidden gem, literally speaking buried behind the jewelry stores on Wabash Avenue.

Oasis Café is a hole in the jewelry shop. It has one of the oddest locations but also one of the tastiest Mediterranean sandwiches. My friend and I both ordered the shish kebab sandwich for $6.99 each. The menu listed on their homepage and Yelp is an outdated version. Most of the prices in the restaurant's menu are at least $1 or $2 more.  The sandwich is a round pita bread stuffed with large chunks of beef, onions, peppers, cucumbers, and mushrooms. It was gushing with flavor and juice. The beef was very well seasoned and peppered. A bib and stack of napkins would be necessary unless you're one of those who eats with knife and fork at all times. I do wish that the pita bread could be slightly thicker though. It was tearing up as I bit through the sandwich.  The restaurant is rather petite but there are enough tables for dine-in. It also has a divided section on the second floor for a quieter experience.

Excellent jewel in the loop, it's in the middle of Wabash but you would never know it. Tucked in the back of a jewelry shop, with a small sign in front. By far the best grab and go Middle eastern fair in the loop, Chicken falafel with tomatoes, hummus and cumbers is a steady meal for me.  One that hasn't changed much in the years i've been a customer. x

The food was a 3, 3.5.  The chicken kabobs were a little dry but the seasoning was tasty. The experience  made it a 4. They were busy at lunch and there was a line but it went fast.  I don't think the three of us waited more than 5 minutes for our food, literally.  I was intrigued that it was hidden in this jewelry store... I would go back.

At first I thought my boyfriend was luring me into some engagement ring trap where he promises delicious Middle Eastern food  in a jewelry store and then subtly brings up our future together while we search for said food. Luckily that wasn't the case as far as the ring shopping goes, and the food definitely didn't disappoint. You kind of get the feeling that the building manager had extra space in the back that he was having trouble renting out and talked some family member into starting a restaurant in the spot. I got the daily special, which was vegetable couscous. Imagine a huge pile of delicious couscous with tender eggplant and sweet potato thrown in and a chewy pita on top for less than $10. It's great, and the portions are so big that I've seriously been eating my leftovers for dinner for the last two days.  Most of the folks at the tables around me had lentil soup, which I regret not ordering. It looks delicious and costs less than $2. For the price and deliciousness levels, this place is hard to beat.

Delicious Middle Eastern fare located inside of a jewelry store on jewler's row in the loop....What is this craziness? It is Oasis Cafe, or, as I like to call it, Ali Baba's Cave of Falafel.  Oasis has a little bit of everything: salads, sandwiches, soups, shawarma, falafel, combination plates for those of us who can't make up our minds. There are plenty of options for both meat eaters and vegetarians, so pretty much everyone can find something to tickle their fancy on the menu. I love the falafel (either the sandwich or the plate), which is always hot and perfectly seasoned with a crispy outside and soft interior. The chicken shawarma is also delicious. But my favorite thing to order is their lentil soup. It is warm and comforting and creamy, and it just tastes amazing. If I get a sandwich, then I always order a side of their hot sauce, as it really helps clear the sinuses. Oasis Cafe is an awesome place to stop in for lunch when in the loop. No, there is no ambiance to speak of. Yes, it is a fast food joint. That being said, everything is tasty, the servings are generous, the prices are affordable, and the service is super quick.

I made a weekend trip to Chicago and wanted something cheap after checking into my hotel.  So I went to Yelp.  The falafel here was good, but the vegetables on the sandwich were only ok.  I just find it hard to believe that this is the best falafel the Loop has to offer.  Sorry, downtown Chicago. The service was super fast (less than a min to make the sandwich), and it's kind of cool that this is in the back of a jewelry mall.  The people in there were regulars so it was nice to not be surrounded by crazy shopping tourists.  Good price, decent food.

Returning here for lunch, I realized I hadn't been here since my last gig in the Loop in 2001. Through much of the 80's and 90's I frequented the Oasis Cafe because it was convenient, a great value, and just pleasingly odd in its location in the back end of a long jewelry mall. I suppose a restaurant in a mall is not odd, but winding your way back to this delicious, friendly and bright spot is something like a weird dream.  The set up is really like a fast food joint, and their food is really fast, unless as I discovered in my last visit, if you order hot tea. That turned into kind of an ordeal, and a good "Big Gulp" serving of hot tea which practically lasted me all afternoon. But I digress from my love of Oasis.The menu is a wonderful combination of, well, combinations, as in plates of deliciously fresh Middle Eastern treats like falafel plates, shawarma, and couscous. Sandwiches, too. Salads like Greek and Lebanese, and many excellent vegetarian offerings. Over the years, I have sampled most of the menu offerings and I was never disappointed. You could eat here everyday, never spend more than ten smackers, and get enough food for your main meal of the day. I had the Chicken Shawarma ($5.49) today. It was filled with tender chicken, chopped cucumbers and tomatoes and a tasty sauce. Very good tongue shui, I must say. This is truly a little hidden gem and one of my top five favorite Loop lunch spots. Rarely crowded and always a good deal.

This place is so unassuming but so delicious. Its in the back of a jewelry mart, but they serve up some excellent, inexpensive (but quality) food. There are a ton of vegetarian options, which I prefer, so I ordered the grape leaves and lentil soup with some cucumbers on the side. The lentil soup was pureed soup, and it tasted amazing. The flavors were perfect, and I love how it was blended. I got, I think, 8 grape leaves on a bed of cucumbers and tomatoes when I ordered the grape leaf plate. Delicious...not greasy at all....and very filling.  My dining partner got the chicken kebab plate, which came with plenty of chicken, rice, beans (??) and hummus. The beans were a bit unusual, but everything else was delicious. We could have easily shared and still been full. The chicken was high quality and flavored nicely, but not too strong. The bill for all this food was $18...which is a nice change of pace in downtown Chicago!  I will definitely be back!

I love falafel, but when I heard that this place was inside a jewelry store, I had to walk the extra couple blocks and get it. I am so glad I did - best falafel in downtown Chicago and worth the extra walk everytime. The falafel balls are perfect -- seasoned right, cooked right. And the prices are the lowest you will get for a lunch that good. Very good hummus. Baba ganoush was just OK, but then I've never loved baba ganoush. I've always hated Jersusalem salad so they let me swap that out in the platter for more hummus. The service is also incredibly fast - a line forms during lunch time but it moves very quickly. And it's not in a jewelry store -- technically it's in a jewelry mall, which consists of lots of various jeweler stands. Either way, the first time you walk in, it's HILARIOUS.

A-OK. Yes a little hard too find, but memorable for that and the march through the den of thieves jewelers when you Finally find the Jewelry Mall address. Certainly a decent low-priced more interesting choice than McDonald's Cafe or Roti, and it could just be that the Jewelry security keeps the panhandlers out of your face in there, hadn't really thought about it after experiencing the opposite at McDonald's Cafe Bfast near Millers B4 11. Not the best falafel, hummus or babagoo I have had by a long shot but plentiful and freshish salad and cucumber ingredients, fairly priced particularly for the neighborhood.  Try Oasis and then you won't have to do it again. IF you get to the NW suburbs try Pita Pita for large hot steaming falafel, and creamy smokey babagoo and much higher quality meats not overseasoned, then try Pita Hut-  greasier and saltier but tasty too in that order.

Great Mediterranean food in the loop. I got the mixed plate. It has a little bit of everything and you definitely get a lot of bang for your buck. Anything you get will taste great. The time from when you order to when you get your food is about 30 seconds (no joke). It's not that they already have food sitting out, it's that they have enough people coming through to continuously make food. Oh yeah, it's also in the back of a jewelery store...

We found this place researching Yelp for a Chicago vacation. Part of any big city vacation for us is local flavor...street food or tucked away funkhouses that excel in the amazing diversity of Mediterranean cuisines. Yeah, it may be hard to find, but we Google street viewed the address, and had no trouble. Just say that strolling through the straight on jewelry aisle to the cafe was mighty awesome. Still pretty busy at 2:00, ordering was  easy and the menu is a delight of flavors and possibilities. My wife ordered the Friday special, couscous with steamed veggies, piled high. More than enough for 2 meals for her. I got the eggplant sandwich, in pita, and the Foul appetizer, but would have hauled off much more, except we had no refrigeration at the hotel. Tasty, tasty and a great deal. Don't forget to ask for a side of the harissa style hot sauce.
Simply one of the best Middle Eastern eateries in Chicago!  Certainly the best one to go to for lunch in the Loop.  A good value and excellent, fresh ingredients.

This place is awesome. In the back of a jewelry store in jeweler's row. I wouldn't have known about it if my coworkers didn't tell me about it. Forget all the other mediterranean places that popped up in the Loop. This place has the best hummus. It's so freaking good. Not too bland like everywhere else. I've only gotten the chicken shawarma but it did not disappoint. Very reasonably priced too. You get a lot of food for your money.

Totally out of the way middle eastern joint.  Very easy to miss if you don't know what you are looking for.  The food is pretty good and the portions are large, but with all of the middle eastern choices in the loop now, I'm not sure i would make this a regular spot.  The chicken Kabobs were very tasty, and they gave you a large portion of them.  The fallafel were also some of the more authentic ones I have had in the loop, but its not worth a 10 block walk when i can hit Naf Naf Grill in 2 blocks.   Go check it out, enjoy the odd sensation of walking through a jewelry store and ending up at a hole in the wall.  Check it off your list, then try something new. And try not to get sucked into buying any cheap ass jewelery in the store.  It all looks like fugazi.   "Fugget abou'it!"

You will walk right past this I'm sure. I did for 3 months and never noticed it. Saw the reviews on Yelp, even then struggled to find it. The food was pretty good - not great. The seating was not so comfortable. They took a while to make my food, but it was pretty good. Large portions, which was nice. I wanted to like this place so much more, then I was introduced to Roti which is closer to my customers, so I never felt the urge to go back. I don't know that I'll ever return, but if I'm shopping for Jewelry under the El trains in the loop, I may stop in. Not a 'destination' by any means.

Ok, again. Falafel. I tried the combination.  I don't know why people crowded there and give the high ratings. In my opinion, it is not good. The environment is not good also.
