If you compare this with other Asian food: Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Thai...  I don't see the point.  Other Mediterranean place like Roti is far better than this one.

Location! Good food from a non-chain restaurant in the middle of downtown for a decent price is hard to come by--Oasis delivers with some delicious hummus and falafel. The fact that it's in the back of jewelry store makes it feel like a "hidden gem".  Har, har.  Yes, I went there.  You should go there too.

Oasis Cafe is definitely one of my favorite lunch spots when I can actually get out of the office for lunch.  The service is SO fast and the portions are huge for the price.  It's hard to find lunch under $6 in the loop, but Oasis Cafe will fill you up for under that.  Obviously it's super weird that it's located in the back of a jewelry store, but I honestly think it's part of the fun of going there!
great little place to grab a falafel sandwich over lunch! very affordable and the falafel sandwiches are great. make sure to ask for hummus and some hot sauce

What's not to like about a Middle Eastern café in the back of a weird little jewelry store?  It's obscure location makes it the equivalent of a hidden little treasure.  The food here is quite good- some of the best falafel in the city.  The pita is fresh, the meat well seasoned.  Legit stuff here.

A little hole-in-the-wall kind of place! The food is cheap but very delicious - you get more food than you would expect! The restaurant is located on Jewelry Row. You have to enter a jewelry store and walk to the back in order to get the restaurant. It's different & fun. It makes you feel like you found that hidden treasure in the city of Chicago! Check it out!

I work across the street and eat here MINIMUM twice a week. Their food is delicious. For the price, they overwhelm you with food.  I wouldn't eat here 2+ times a week if I didn't think it was delicious! Such a gem in the city of Chicago!

The food is so cheap. I had a falafel wrap and it was delicious. Mediterranean tastes like mediterranean and this place was delicious. Also it is hidden in the back of a mall on Jewelers' Row. So yes: walk all the way in. All the way in.

Ridiculously hard to find if you are a tourist.... we passed this place 3 times before we saw their tiny sign BUT it was worth the frustration.  I would recommend the baba ganoush- absolute best I have ever had.  Good sized portions and seemed very fresh.

I'm a bit torn, because pita at a place like this should be good and it wasn't I would almost go 3 stars...but I'm in a generous mood. I had the falafel and hummus plate and everything but the pita was really tasty. Crunchy falafel with pillowy insides, creamy and intense hummus, crisp veg in the little side salad. But, the pita was overly floury and a bit...anemic to be honest. I would try this place again and get something where the pita isn't as much of a major component. The location at the back of the jewelry mall is fun and quirky,  too!

Great little hidden spot.  Nothing like walking through a jewelry store to get falafel!  Delicious food and very reasonable price.  It's not fancy - plastic plates, utensils, tray but it's darn good!  Excellent falafel, fab hummus!  Definitely stop by this place when you're hungry for Mediterranean.

This place was amazing...until I found a pubic hair in my hummus. Seriously, I would have murdered for my Friday fix of Oasis hummus, chicken shawarma and a side of falafel.  In fact, everything on the menu was spectacular - and I've been to the Middle East and to a number of Mediterranean restaurants throughout Chicago, NYC, LA and a handful of European cities.  This place really was top notch - not to mention the great prices and generous portions. But there's just something about another dude's pube in your mouth that I have forever decided, this is no longer my Friday loop lunch place of choice.  Maybe it's yours; give it a try, you'll love it.  But I just can't.  I still have nightmares. And yes, I also planned on taking my girlfriend there just to see the look on her face as we walk in to a large jewelry store, only to direct her to the peculiarly located Mediterranean sanctuary, or Oasis if you will, in the rear.

Let start by saying this is a hidden gem in the downtown area. It is hidden all the way in the back of a mini jewelry mall. I was so excited about trying this place because I've heard about it on t.v.. and I love middle eastern food. I had their  mix combo with beef kaftsa and falafels which also comes with a salad, hummus, pita bread and rice. I loved it the food was great and very filling. My tummy was very happy. Please, try this place is you're walking down wabash avenue, it is a true gem.

Don't be confused, this place is at the back of a jewelry store (well mall for that fact). It threw us off at first. DO NOT let that discourage you from trying this place.  We were walking around millenium park and needed some food. Not wanting to eat at the grill right there at the park we decided to venture down the street a little. Boy are we glad! We didn't have any idea what we wanted to order so we took probably 10 minutes looking over the menu. The cashier was super friendly. Although they have "daily specials" we chose something else, a combo plate with kifta and a kifta sandwich. Both were AMAZING!  You can't really go wrong for the price. I got the sandwich, about $6 total. It filled me up to where I didn't have to eat dinner. This place was a diamond in the rough and boy are we glad we found it.

For fast food Mediterranean, this place is awesome. I had the kafta special and my boyfriend had the kafta sandwich, which was a little difficult to eat being so big. Throughout our meal he kept saying, "Man, I should have ordered what you got." Yum, and I would definitely come back.

you know when you go out shopping for a new gold necklace, and you just get so exhausted trying on all that bling that you need some mediterranean refreshments?  well oasis cafe knows.  that's why they're conveniently located at the back of a jewelry store.  i won't say it's the best mediterranean food i've had (i live in ny after all), but it was darn tasty.  also, super cheap.  and also, SO FAST! i've never been served faster.  they put that hummus platter together like forest gump assembling a weapon.  if you're in a rush and need some falafel and some hoop earrings, head here.

Good price lunch spot in the jewelry row.  You do have to walk into the jewelry store front and walk to the back.  Had the veggie platter, really well spiced fresh falafel, baba ganoush and humus.  And the daily special(Moroccan chicken) is super good value too!

After being in the area and reading some glowing reviews, I headed into Oasis Cafe.  Boy, did I feel like I was struttin' the jewelry store catwalk on my way to get me some delicious Mediterranean food.   They have daily specials, but I wasn't feelin' chicken.  No, I get lamb whenever I see it offered, because I love lamb.  Love. I ordered a Beef & Lamb Kufta sandwich and 3 falafels.  Well...I ordered 3, and after I got back to my destination I saw they gave me 4, so I'm not sure if I paid for the last one.  Hmmm. Ah well; the more falafels, the merrier.  And what delicious falafels!  Wow.  They were nicely spiced and probably the best ones I've had in my short falafel experience. Sadly there was no sauce; I probably had to ask for it, but didn't even think to do so at the time.  The kufta sandwich was also amazing - it had grilled zucchini, yellow squash, and other veggies in a delicious pita.  My previous kufta sandwich experiences did not include squash (rather, lettuce and onions), so this was amazing to me.  It was so juicy that some of the pita started tearing.  Mmm, juice. I was seriously contemplating going back the next day to try one of their specials (which seems like a much better deal), but talked myself into trying something else.  I WILL be back to Oasis Cafe, though.  What a hidden gem! :)
I LOVE this place. Great food, good prices -- its a hidden gem! I feel like it should be featured on "Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives" :)

Yummy yummy yummy!  After many recommendations, I finally tried Oasis Cafe yesterday (7/12/12) and I gotta say, it was delicious.  Had the veggie platter.  Don't be shy...enter through the jewelry store and walk to the back.  You'll be glad you did!

Best falafel sandwich in the loop! Daily specials are fresh and taste like homecooked. Have been back quite a few times as we get hooked on it here in the office! Cheap, reasonably priced and just downright tasty!
Had a sampler plate with flaffal, chicken, rice, hummus, pita and salad. All was really tasty!  Reasonable price and good amount of food! Will be go back!
Awesome lunch in the Loop--quick and delicious, and tucked away in the back of a jewelry shop, which makes it feel like a fancy little surprise.

The food here is consistently delicious (the tabouleh fresh and lemony, the dolmas flavorful without being to oily, the pita warm and fresh, etc.).  It's also such an amusing gimmick to walk past couples picking engagement rings one your way to lunch. I believe the jewelry has to be bargained for, so perhaps it's not the best place for an impulse purchase, however.  It's mainly a weekday lunch place, but it's open for lunch on Saturday now as well.

Had the chicken shwarma sandwich.  Really liked the chicken and hummus, everything else was just ok.  Cool location, but food is lackluster.  Other two guys I went with disliked this place more than me.

Great value; horrible pita. Pita is an indispensible element of most of the items I order here and its suckiness overshadows the good falafel, hummus, baba ghanoush, etc. It literally ruins the lunch. It's a shame because I generally like everything else here. Step up yo pita game, Oasis!

Ok when people say it's hard to find they are not kidding but that's part of the adventure but soooooo worth the search. Yes, you really do need to traverse a full out jewelry store to get to the yummi-ness but it's worth it! Both the hubby and I had pitas (chicken and lamb).  Expertly seasoned meat and fresh pita bread = awesome lunch.  We were disappointed to see that we missed the couscous Friday and if we lived in Chicago we would most definitely be back. They serve the food in wax paper and paper plates so if you are looking for something fancy this is not it, but if you are looking for a tasty, affordable meal then check out Oasis.

Artfully hidden in the back of the jewelry store, presumably so you can enjoy some sparkle with your Falafel, this is the place that you'll likely only discover because someone else brings you there - as was the case with me. A great little Loop lunchtime escape, I find myself here fairly regularly.  If you want to pay less than $10 for lunch in the Loop, your options are pretty limited to the $5 footlong, or a handful of fast food places.  So it's always refreshing to find a place like this where $10 will fill you up and leave plenty of change in your pockets. They're crazy fast, they're affordable, and if you go there on a Wednesday, their stuffed chicken breast is pretty awesome.  Fortunately enough, their baba ganouj and falafel are great all of the rest of the days. Best Mediterranean food in the city?  No.  But certainly the best you'll find in the Loop at this price.  Definitely worth accidentally forgetting your lunch at home every so often...
Heaven in your mouth hole. Tasty treat for the taste buds. Your wallet won't frown.

It's important to mention that this place is in the back of a jewelry store. Whoever came up with that idea is a genius because I'm sure both establishments feed off each other ( WINK ). What's most important to mention is that mediterranean food in Chicago is by and large underwhelming and bland. Sultan's Market, Oasis Cafe, these places only stay in business because of the price and the lack of a good alternative, in my opinion. I do have an urge for shawarma and hummus sometimes, so this place gets my business whenever I'm feeling it, but I long for the days of Sunrise Pita in Sunrise, Florida.

Considering that Oasis is tucked away in the back of a jewelry store and impossible to find, I'd say it's a hidden gem.   It's the best mediterranean place in the Loop, and having been to the middle east several times and being a HUGE fan of the cuisine, I'm picky: -Awesome falafel, with a crisp exterior and a green-tinged (and therefore more authentic), flavorful and warm interior -TENDER pieces of chicken breast, really impressive that they can take what's such a dry piece of meat into juicy goodness -Fresh and lemony tabouleh -Smokey baba ganouj and velvety hummus -Creamy and savory lentil soup -And being a condimental gal, I love my tahini and hot sauce, which you can request in little containers on the side Huge portions, great flavor, reasonable prices, and quick turnover which make lunchtime seating possible?  This is definitely my work week oasis.

It deserves 4 stars because the prices are cheap, portions are large, the jewelry store location is cool and the service was friendly. But honestly, I thought the food was just alright. I ordered the chicken shawarma plate and while the chicken is worth going back for, the hummus, pita and rice are not. The lentil soup was warm and satisfying, and when I return I will order it along with the tabouleh salad, only because I have had my fair share and I'd like to compare.   I hear their falafel is awesome, but unfortunately I have never been a fan, so I probably won't be trying it. If you want to do lunch in the loop, check it out; it's an experience, just not necessarily the best Mediterranean food.
Great spot would have never know about this place without yelp. Love the falafal sandwich
Follow the path to the Oasis, you will be rewarded with a tasty lunch.  The only downside were the beans. A few were undercooked but the rest of the Kafta plate was delicious and fresh.
My favorite falafel sandwich in the city.  Shawarma plates are HUGE, definitely filling.

Pretty solid Mediterranean food, even though it's tucked away and easy to miss. A coworker of mine took me here one day and I ordered a chicken kebab sandwich. It was pretty delicious, and I remember my food was affordable ($6-7) and fresh.  The only awkward thing here is the seating arrangement. It gets pretty full fast, so I suggest you get here during irregular lunch hours (like between 1pm and 2pm).
Would never have found this place without Yelp. Great tasting food at good value... but little weird walking through all the Jewelers to get a kebab

This place is one of The Loop's best-kept secrets.  The most awesome thing about it is that you have to walk through some jewelry mall to get there. It's like this gauntlet of fancypants jewelers who are probably completely exasperated at having to deal with downtown business-y lunchers everyday. The actual seating area is fairly generic, but who cares? The bizarre location definitely makes up for it. The hummus is amazing, and the falafel is excellent as well. Be sure to get the hot sauce, too. It's a little on the spicy side but delicious. Oh, and they have fountain Diet Dr. Pepper, which is rare.  The register guy is cooly efficient and and all the kitchen dudes are nice, helpful and tolerant of frequent requests for extra pita bread or hot sauce.

For me, it was all the hype about eating in the rear of a jewelry store that led me to this establishment after seeing a segment about it on "190 North", and I left feeling satisfied and impressed! After walking down the "runway of jewels and diamonds" (at least that is how I felt walking through the store lol), I ordered the chicken kabob plate. Initially I just wanted the sandwich, but I am also a hummus fanatic so I got the plate which offered two kabobs, hummus, rice and beans. Although the chicken was a little (just a little) on the dry side, it was still very tasty. Everything else that came with the plate was flavorful and plentiful. I was full by the end of my meal. I cannot complain because the cost was very reasonable. Good customer service (very nice guys behind the counter). I really thought it was cool eating in a jewelry store, especially people watching those looking at jewelry. A litte weird, but fun nonetheless. Tip: A friend of mine wanted some feta with his meal, and it was a dollar extra for about an 1/8 cup. Not sure what other "extras" they are and what they cost, but for the quantity given, it wasn't really worth a dollar.

The only thing better than the food was the squirrel on some dude's head on the way in.  He doesn't even know it's there.  Pass 6-7 shady jewelers and then you are presented with a gift from god on the left.  From a distance you may think it's a motorcycle helmet but it is not!  As you approach this fine piece of art, have two things ready: - camera - barf bag Trust me you'll use both.  Do not make eye contact.  Just look at his piece and grin.  He's used to it.  Give him two thumbs up!

I've been here many, many times and have enjoyed it most of the time. The food isn't that pricey, but can be if you decide to try a few different things. My favorite dish is the Chicken Kabobs and some falafel with hummus on the side. Its not all that healthy for you, but its so damn good. Give it a try if you're up for some pretty tasty, and cheap, Mediterranean food.

Full disclosure - I've been there a couple dozen times and ordered the same thing every time. The chicken shawarma is the best I've had in the city of Chicago.  It was awkward for me the first couple times walking through a jewelry store to get to it - don't let it be for you. Own that jewelry store aisle like it's a catwalk and strut right through there (God knows they're used to it anyway). Delicious, cheap, quick. Great spot if you can find it.

I've only been to this place twice, and incidentally, almost exactly a year apart. Don't expect a fancy restaurant, plenty of seating, or anything you might refer to as "ambience". Although, you do have to walk through a diamond shop, right down an aisle of goods to get to.. falafel? For some reason, I like this. Like I'm heading to a hidden speakeasy, except for hummus and tahini. Okay, I'm going to type this in caps, for the people who skim paragraphs for caps, because I don't want anyone to miss this part of my review: THESE ARE THE BEST FALAFEL SANDWICHES IN CHICAGO. I lived in the Middle East up until last year, meaning 20-something years, so I can vouch for these as being pretty damn good. Great for a quick "fast-food" lunch on days I'm too lazy to cook, and/or if I'm craving a taste of home. Also, they're pretty big sandwiches. The first time I visited the shop, it seemed that the owners were behind the counter. I'd just moved to Chicago so hearing a little bit of Arabic was also worth the visit for me. Anyway, delicious falafel, check it out next time you need to grab a Loop lunch in a hurry.

Went this past week for lunch. Definitely one of those hole-in-the-wall places. Don't expect a nice environment (it's located in the back of a jewelry store) but the food was excellent. For what I ordered the prices weren't bad either. There was a long line, which is always a good indicator.  Would definitely go back.

Oasis, where have you been all my life?!  The food here is simply delicious! And served quickly! I always get the mixed combination lunch special: falafel, hummus, and your choice of either chicken or kifta (kifta is lamb or beef or a mix of both). It is served with tahini sauce to dip the falafel, and pita, which is sliced so you can make a pita pocket or just dip it into things like I do. My experience at Oasis usually goes something like this: Dip pita into Hummus: Did I just grunt? Pop Falafel in my mouth: Close my eyes and sigh.  Bite into Kifta: Begin humming and swaying side to side. And the best thing is, when you walk in you will see a really, really long line. Dont' leave! They work that line like it's nobody's business. I've never been served food this quickly - not even at McDonald's. This is super fast and super good food!

Experienced the inevitable awkwardness of walking through a jewelry mall to get to the actual cafe. My friend and I went there for a Saturday lunch so it wasn't busy at all. We really enjoyed the food there. The staff was very speedy and friendly. I had the veggie comboe for around $8 after tax. It was a very generous portion. I feel like falafel is a very personal food - I like it more moist than what I had at Oasis Cafe. The pita was also a bit cold and dry, so when I tried to stuff the ingredients in it fell apart, altho it might be that I had crappy stuffing skills. My friend loved her kebob sandwich and the hot sauce was very uniquely flavorful. A bit goes a long way. With a variety of items to choose from, I will definitely go back again. You can't find that many better lunch options than this in the Loop.

This is an amazing find... in the back of a Jewelry store! I've had their falafel sandwich, their lamb shish-kebob sandwich... the lamb which they grill fresh for you... and they are both amazing. Great stuff... not to be missed. And darn inexpensive too! $4.50 for a falafel sandwich...
Geese, Lois! This felafel is so (,so, so) good! And the hot sauce! TDF! TLDF!  Plus, the getting there is a treat! Buy some diamonds while you wait.

Great place for a couple of bitches to have a quick lunch and bask in each other's fabulousness. Not all that super duper special, but the food is good, fresh and quick. Love that is in such a random place, back of a jewelry store - that is fun.  I'm going to have to go back to really judge this place. I had the Kofte, which I am always a fan of, and it was pretty good. Solid place for lunch, definitely.
Solid lunch option in the loop. Good falafel and great lentil soup. Prices have gone up a bit lately though.

Food: 4 Decor: 2 Service: 3 I came here with a friend for lunch around noon Friday, right before checking into Lollapalooza. The place is hidden inside a jewelry store, and it took us some backtracking before we were able to find it. I opted for the chicken shawarma plate, and my friend opted for the Moroccan couscous with chicken. The chicken shawarma was prepared nicely, and the portions were very generous. My Jewish friend kept raving about how the food was super authentic and just like her mother's cooking. Both dishes were $7, and I was absolutely stuffed afterwards.
Kefta Plate was amazing. This place is a hidden gem. Don't forget to ask for their homemade hot sauce.
Great authentic middle-eastern food. Always fresh and tasty. Quick service; don't leave when you see a long line, it goes by fast.

Get your falafel fix here!  I work around the corner and have been reluctant to write a review for fear my favorite place would become too overcrowded.  Alas, the word is out.  I just avoid the peak lunch hour now.  The food is amazing.  I recommend the plates so that you can get a mix of flavors, but my go to is still the falafel/hummus plate.  Chicken shwarma is pretty amazing if you want something to really fill you up.  The staff is friendly and will always answer questions.  A hidden gem in the loop - if you can find it.

Pay attention to the address or you might miss it! I found this place using Google Maps. I was craving baba ganoush and was looking for someplace near my office. I walked right past it the first time. If I had looked on yelp, I would have seen that it is located in the back of a jewelry mall. It was around 1pm, so there wasn't a huge crowd, but there was definitely a steady inflow of customers the whole time I was there. The service was fast; total time from getting in line to receiving my food was less than 5 minutes. I ordered the veggie plate, which includes falafel, baba ganoush, hummos, vegetarian grape leaves, and a piece of pita. The food was reasonably price and was really good. There is also seating, so I was able to relax in the A/C instead of taking my food to-go or eating at my desk. You should really try this place!
omg.....fresh with flavor!!!! must check it out for yourself. chef papi perez
Great falafel and quick service.  I enjoyed it.  I like the jewelry store atmosphere...  I would have never known it was there if somebody hadn't told me.  Will definitely be back.

This is my go-to spot for an inexpensive lunch when I'm around the Loop. It's location in the back of a jewelry mall gives it a tranquil feel - far from the bustle of the street. Well, maybe tranquil is a bit exaggerated but it's certainly quieter than many storefront loop options. Take note of the address before embarking, as there are a few jewelry malls on that side of the street in the area. I found this out the hard way by ushering a handful of hungry diners into the wrong mall and walking all the way to the back before realizing my error. The food is solid Mediterranean/Middle-Eastern fare. Can't miss with the falafel and hummus offerings. Don't miss the hot sauce as a condiment if you like it spicy.

Food was great.  Service was fast.  Don't know what else to say other than give it a try.  I got the combo plate and the chicken shwarma was delicious (not dry like it often is), the kefta kabob had great flavor and the falafel were the best I've ever eaten.   They make a homemade hot sauce that is a must.  I'll be back.  Don't let having to walk though a jewelry store turn you off.  Give it a try.
There food is awesome. Has the authentic taste and is price i can say "cheap". I love their falafals and actually most of the stuff. Their platters are great.

Best falafel I have ever eaten and at $5 dollars this might be the best buy for lunch in the entire loop. Sure I could get a subway sandwich which might be more filling but this delectable little spot provides the perfect amount of food and it is delish.  Also, the fact that it is in back of a jewelry store adds some extra flare to it. it makes you feel like you're part of the in crowd and no one else knows about it but you. Check this place out!

People use the term "hidden gem" much too often. This time, its warranted.  To get into Oasis Cafe, you walk through a jewelry store, all the way to the back to find a truly delicious, hidden gem in the heart of Jeweler's Row. The lentil soup is creamy and amazing. The filafel sandwiches even better and flavorful. The prices cannot be beat and the service is fast and efficient.  You will feel like a part of a special club while you eat with your fellow diners as you watch people walk by with no idea what they are missing.  Enjoy.

Yummy yummy yummy! Five dollar falafels in the back of a jewelry store. Plus, the place had a line nonstop and this was after the lunch rush would typically end on a workday.  My friend got the kafta kabob sandwich and it blew her mind. As I stated already, I went with a falafel after a tough decision between that and the Moroccan Chicken dish, which was the focal point for my food envious eye when I wasn't enjoying my falafel. The falafel was excellent and definitely beats any falafel where I live (Indianapolis).

I've avoided Oasis Cafe in the past, deterred by the jewelry store you must go through to reach it at the back.  I went here for lunch on a weekday and found it's a very popular spot.  I ordered the Wabash Special, which for $6.99 comes with a "burrito," beans, hummus and veggies, and pita bread. I'm not used to Mediterrannean food but thought this was good, although it left me very full, and I'd go back to try some of their other options- the ones with rice looked like they might have more flavor. Well-priced, convenient, and healthy (I think).

I must say that I wasn't too sure about visiting a restaurant located at the back of a jewelry store but I'm so glad that I did.  Let's see... tasty food-check quality ingredients-check  reasonable prices, good portions-check customer friendly and fast-check What else do you need? Just go already

I know it's politically incorrect to say it in this country, especially in the Midwest, but the portions are far too large!  Being on a diet, this is the only thing that keeps me from coming back more often (well, that and the difficulty I have remembering where it is).  C'mon folks--make me happy AND improve your margins--how can you go wrong? :-) I was last in there two days ago, and I still can't get that amazing, fall-off-the-bone Moroccan chicken out of my head! The service here is fast AND friendly.  Don't let anyone tell you you can't have it both ways.

Ever checked to see how many Mediterranean restaurants there are in the Loop? It's outrageous... This is one of my personal favorites... buried inside the jewlery mall requires diners to know what to look for. Bottom line:   Get there early if possible as the line can get very long  Everything is amazing, portions are generous mmm craving some falafel now

I have to explain everything I ordered in a little detail to explain my rating... 1. The falafel sandwich was good and filling. Zad's is better. 2. Everytime I have had lemon rice soup from other places, it is creamy and delicious. This lemon rice soup was not creamy at all, had peppers in it, and seemed very high in sodium. I ate less than half of it. 3. I bought a bottle of apple juice, and I'm pretty sure it had gone bad, because it tasted like a slightly rotting apple. However, the staff let me replace it with a Snapple iced tea once I told them it tasted bad. The staff was nice, and the sandwich was good, so I will possibly come back here again, but I will try lentil soup and stray away from any juices.

I normally get take out. here The cafe is not much to look at- but that is not why people come here. They come for the food. I love this little hole in the wall place, I come here on average once a week and I always get the same thing. The falafel sandwhich is very very good - I have tried many kinds and this is by far the best in the Loop. I also get their Baklava. And you might not think this is the place to go for Baklava - but I love Baklava and I try it at almost all places I go that offer it and this one by far is my favorite!!! Just the right amount of everything. Try it you will not be sorry. I understand this place also does catering, something to think about.

Hidden in the back of a jewelry store, this quick lunchtime spot is excellent. It's decently priced, tasty and convenient. The lunch line can be long, but never fear. It moves quickly. It's a refreshing alternative to the downtown chains.

One of my favorite lunch spots in the loop.  The food is great, the prices are right, the portions are very large, and the service is quick.  I love the combo plate, and the falafel sandwich is unreal.  One of the most fun things about it though, is that it is in the very back of a jewlery store.  So random, but I think that it adds something.  If you've never been here before, do yourself a huge solid and get there...NOW!

My favorite Mediterranean place for lunch in the Loop. Great prices, filling portions, friendly service and awesome lunch specials. Personally, I always wait until Tuesday (Moroccan Chicken) and Wednesday (Napoli stuffed chicken). Its so good, I almost have a Pavlovian reflex by mid-week. The Cafe is located in the back of a set of independent jeweler counters so its definitely hard to find. Therefore, the fact that they are so busy all the time is further proof that this place is doing it right.

Oasis is my favorite place to get lunch in the loop. Under $10, you can't beat it. A little hard to find but hard to forget.  Lunch specials everyday and great mediterranean menu. Herrera soup is amazing and the chicken schwarma plate is big enough to share. Get there early for fried pita scraps free at the pick up counter!

I'd read about this restaurant on Yelp back in December and had been meaning to get downtown to try it ever since. Today I woke up and felt the need to try something new and luckily the Oasis Cafe popped into my head. It's a good thing others had described so well where it is located or I'd have probably never found it.  I'm new to Middle Eastern food so I had no idea what I was getting into, but I had faith based on the very favorable reviews here that I'd like it. I found myself a bit intimidated by all the strange and interesting names on the menu so I decided to play it safe and order a combo plate.  That turned out to be an excellent choice for a first timer! I don't know what all the items on the plate were,but  I can tell you that without exception it was a party for my taste buds. The chicken had a shockingly great flavor and was not dry like white chicken meat can be. Also, the fried rice had a good flavor and it too was not dried out like a lot of restaurants serve.  It's guaranteed that I will be back, and can't wait to introduce friends and family to this little gem held hidden inside the loop.

I'm just gonna break it down and review everything I've eaten here: -falafel plate and/or sandwich: DELICIOUS!!! I have absolutely no complaints! Well...maybe one...it only lasts for a minute cause I wolf it down so quickly. -kifta kebab (beef) plate: a bit on the dry side but definitely flavorful -shish kebab (lamb) sandwich: Yummmmm. I don't know about you guys but I can't think of anywhere downtown where I could get me some tasty lamb action except this joint.  -vegetarian plate: I'm not a huge fan of the stuffed grape leaves because they're a little bit on the dry side but everything else on the plate is awesome -lentil soup: pretty tasty...it's not like the best soup ever but honestly, I always get it as a side for something else and it goes great with everything My biggest complaint? WHY DON'T THEY SELL THOSE PITA CHIPS THEY LEAVE OUT FOR YOU TO EAT??? THAT STUFF IS SOOOOO GOOOOOOOOOD
A little hard to find and kind of a weird location but the serve solid middle eastern food. I usually go with the kafta or the falafel and I haven't been dissapointed.

I'm mad that I didn't know about this place sooner!  As everyone else has said it's a little hidden gem on Jeweler's Row.  They are friendly, and SUPER fast.  Everything I've tried so far has been great, their falafel is awesome.  I also love their hummus and the rice wrapped up like cute little burritos in grape leaves.  I'm here once a week now that I've discovered it!

This is the best $4 you will ever spend on a falafel sandwich. This is also the most random ass place to eat for lunch. It is in a jewelry store and you feel weird going in because you just want to eat. They give you a decent amount of food. They have daily specials that are well worth the price. Check it out and you will be pleasantly surprise. Perfect place for a person buying an engagement ring and filling their belly ;) PS: Avoid the 12pm hour, the place gets crazy packed (though you get your food fast, you might not have anywhere to sit).

I have eaten here about four times.  It's quick, unique, and doesn't make me feel too greasy.  The food isn't great though.  I made the mistake of getting Thursday's special twice (duh!), and it was underwhelming both times.  It's better than same old subway etc.

Yup - it's true - you enter via a jewellery store.  Glad I read that in a review here on Yelp - and glad other Yelpers pointed the way.  It's basically a little hole-in-the wall, at the back of a jewellery "mall".  They seem to have daily specials, and a regular menu.  Decor leaves something to be desired. I'd give it a 3.5 if 1/2 stars were allowed... Staff are efficient and nice - however they have a constant stream of customers, so don't expect them to stop and actually chat - no time! Prices are reasonable, and servings are good.  Food is tastey.  We ate everything.  :-)  I had a variety plate with Kefta, hubby had Shwarma sandwhich. It was wonderful to eat some Medditaranean food, something that is sadly missing from the area we live in. Would I recommend: Yes Would I return:  Yes
The food is a solid four.   The last star is for the weird location in the back of a jewelry mall, the reasonable prices and the fast service even at the height of the lunch rush.

My buddy DJ A has been raving about this place for a while now. And this past Friday he was bugging me to head over to 21 N. Wabash with him. So we grabbed another co-worker and headed over to the Oasis Cafe for a Friday lunch.  Well I ordered the Oasis Kefta special. This came with grilled ground meat that was served over rice with hummus, veggies and foul. I thought it was just average, nothing to truly write home about. I also grabbed a bottle of water and my total lunch bill came to just over $9 dollars. The food was truly just average tasting, no memorable spices or flavorings or anything.  The veggies were pretty good though.  It wasn't bad, I just know I have had better.  The Oasis Cafe is a little place that is tucked away in the back of a jewelry store. The service was nice, not too friendly, but nice. I did experience some bad after taste of my meal 2 to six hours after eating my meal. I wasn't sick but just a real funky after taste for quite a while.  I think it was the ground meat.  So will I go back with my buddy DJ A to give the Oasis Cafe another try? I would say yes, but the next time I will try something different than the Oasis Kefta.

I have been to most of the middle eastern places in Chicago. Oasis definitely has the tastiest falafels. The hummus and baba ghanouj are also top notch. I find the grape leaves a little too salty , but maybe they are supposed to be that way. Just knocking them down one star for the decor/atmosphere.

5 stars for price to value - delicious, huge portion for the $, and bizarrely located; a food coma waiting to happen Word of warning: If you plan on sitting upstairs, it is at least 15 degrees hotter up there - think twice before ordering double hot sauce.

Such a nice change from the boring lunch scene in the loop... everything at Oasis taste fresh, i esp love the Moroccan Chicken special on tuesdays!! but seriously everything else are good too quick and friendly service, huge portion size and reasonable pricing, i am a fan!!!

SO GOOD!  I've been working on Wabash for two years and just now went here. It is a bit hard to find because like the other reviews said you have to walk through the jewelry store to get there.  I was not sure what to expect because the menu does not really say what each plate comes with (i.e. pita, tahini)  Since I have food commitment issues I went with the mixed combination plate which was 3 delicious pieces of falafel, baba ghanouj, a huge portion of rice and then I selected the kefta. I could easily eat this for three days. So much food all for less than $8.  Was not sure what to expect from the kefta, but rather than being a ground meat kefta it was juicy steak meat. So tender and AHMA-ZING!!! The plate came with tahini, hot sauce and a pita. I can't believe I've waited so long to try this place.

This is a hidden gem in the Loop... a lunchtime staple for me and my colleagues. Where else can you walk by cases of diamonds AND order amazing falafel, chicken shawarma, hummus, and baba ganoush? Sure it's a hole in the wall and you have to know about it to find it, but the prices and the quality of food is amazing. It's always fresh and the service is super fast, which is perfect when I realize I forgot my lunch and need something quick to eat before my next meeting.  I typically get my food to go, but it's nice to know there's a small seating area where you can watch people shopping for jewelry.  I highly recommend Oasis Cafe. Go there now!

OMG this is the best Hummus ever.  I crave it.  I can eat this everyday.  I would even if I had to work everyday.  Please open one near my home, or deliver to my home.  I love you.  You are affordable and delish!!!
This is a great little secret hole in the wall lunch spot in the loop. They are fast, food is great... it just gets crowded.
Although this little gem is hidden, well, behind some jewelers, if you can find it, Oasis Cafe will make your day. Cheap, delicious, and super fast, what more can you ask for?

Just had lunch for the first time here and let me tell you, it's pretty badass. My friend Kaori recommended it to me and told me where to go. I got lost for a minute, but then I realized that it's hidden behind the jewelry store. Because it's hidden, it's not touristy (a plus) and makes you feel like you're part of a exclusive club. Imagine going into an awesome nightclub through the alley and into the kitchen. That's how I felt walking through here. The cool part is that people actually eat on the glass counter (you know, where you would normally put jewelry for display) at the end of the jewelry store. One thing you should know about me; I love hole-in-the-wall places. I think it bring me back to when I'm in Thailand or Hong Kong, where it's all about the food and not about silverware. You come to a restaurant to eat, right? Great food. Super fast service (I think I got my chicken sandwich faster than I would have at Jimmy Johns).

Seemed funny to go through a jewelry store, until we saw the line of 20+ people in back! Even with that many people, we made it through the line and had our food in well under 10 minutes. And the food would have been worth a wait far longer than that! Amazing. Delicious. Tons of vegetarian options. Fantastic little gem of a place!

Yes, this place is in the back of a jewelry store. Yes, this is a totally legit falafal place. Yes, you really should stop reading these reviews and just go eat here. I have really really high standards for falafals. I've been spoiled my entire life by a little falafal joint near where I grew up. I am usually disappointing when I try a new falafal place because they usually just don't compare. This place is REALLY GOOD. I wish I found this place earlier (sadly I found it 1 week before moving away from Chicago). The falafal sandwich was definitely up to my standards.

This, my friends, is as good as it gets. You won't find a better hole in the wall place than this. You literally can't get to this place without walking through a jewelry store. Don't let that freak you out. The people who work there won't try to get you to buy anything as you walk by. Unless, of course, you WANT to buy a sketchy looking watch. Anyway, Oasis is a lunch favorite of mine. I don't think I've ever spent more than 5 minutes in the store, and that might be stretching it! You can get in, order, get out, and be eating so fast you'll wonder why you haven't been here before.  All of the food is lunch priced, if you know what I mean. I usually get the Chicken Kabob plate. That comes with 2 Chicken Kabobs, rice, beans, hummos, and a large pita. Seriously, I can't ever finish this thing and its under $7!!! I highly suggest you eat here. Now... WTF why are you still reading? Seriously go. Takeaways: Cheap, Amazing, Mediterranean food in the back of a jewelry store. Nuff Said.

Woohoo! It's really as good as it gets. The fact that you walk in a jewelry store to get there makes me love it anyway. Period.  Even if the food was average, I would still find it very amusing.  Now for the important part. The food is made with care and fresh ingredients. We went in right around noon and the cashier girl is polite, cheerful and a little bit no nonsense.  She is already helping the next person as she is ending your transaction.  Talk about moving the line right along. Which is very helpful, because at one point today, I counted thirty people in line. She moved them in and out very quickly.  Seating is very limited, so if  getting your lunch to go is an option, that might be a better way. Food comes up very quickly. They do not waste any time at Oasis Cafe. We ordered a veggie plate and a meat combo plate.  Plenty of hummus, baba gahnoush, bread, tabouli, grape leaves and a little salad.  The hummus is really smooth and full of flavor and the baba gahnoush is smokideliciousness.  We also ordered two lentil soups, the lentil soup is pureed smooth, rich and creamy, it did not taste diet by any means.  Oasis isn't just a band.

The special on Monday & Wednesday is called KUSHARI. This dish is the most amazing Mediterranean dish ever! Perfect blend of lentils, rice, veggies and schwarma. You can get it without meat but Oasis has the best schwarma I ever had! If you like it spicy, ask for some hot sauce and you will have an amazing lunch. Enough food for 2 days, no joke!

Once a restaurant has over 100 reviews for it, I sometimes fear there is really no need to expand in great detail upon one's experience there. It's either clearly great, fair, or meh comparably. For this reason, my review of Oasis Cafe will be brief although my admiration for this place will remain long lasting.  This place was delicious. It's very likely that follow up visits and an opportunity to try more items (and maybe if one of the jewelers wanted to throw a lovely ring my way on my venture out of the store) would result in a 5 star review, but I'll stick with 4 for now. I had a special chicken dish with spinach, peppers and feta stuffed inside. The chicken was moist and well seasoned. The rice - i'm admittedly not a big rice fan - was perfectly cooked as was the accompanying pita. Additionally, the falafel are divine.  Added bonus: diet dr. pepper in the fountain with DIY drinks and economically non-friendly styrofoam. Bad for the ecosystem I'm well aware, but nothing but styrofoam keeps my drink icy for hours.  This place is legitimately delicious.
Best falafel I've had outside Paris. Weird that it's in a jewelry store?  Yes. Super cheap, super delicious lunch?  Yes. Also I would eat a bucket of the hummus with a spoon if they'd let me.

This has turned into one of my favorite lunch spots this summer. I feel the prices are reasonable for what you get. The food is great and service is fast paced. If you're ordering a sandwich, get it with hummus for a dollar extra. The bottom of your pita will be filled with it.  I wish there was more seating available, but it's downtown, that's how it goes. I would recommend this place to anyone looking for something a little different. It's better than Subway or hot dogs.

A GEM hidden amongst GEMS. Get it? Because it's hidden behind a jewelry store? har har har.... My new favorite Loop Falafel, hands down. I wonder if they'll add baba gannouj in my sandwich next time? hhmmmm.... mmmmm~ Overheard at the door: "Wait, where are we going for lunch?" "Did you need something from here?" "Is this... the entrance?" My favorite: "..Are yOU GONNA BUY ME SOMETHING?!"

Aiight so the location is a bit questionable. Being hidden in the back of a Jewelry store in the Wabash jewelry district doesn't exactly scream "Come in and get some yummy food". Everytime I walk in there the huge guard looks at me like I'm planning to steal some bling. Little does he know I am there for the real treasure, that's right the Chicken Shawarma.  I have been to plenty of Middle Eastern places but this one never disappoints. I have tried the Falafel sammich, the shish-kabob, the Napoli chicken (Wed only) and everything was delicious. Despite the location, the place is clean and has dine-in space. The prices are just ridiculous for the quality you will get Definitely worth a visit
This is one of my favorite lunch loop spots. Fabulous hummus, falafel etc. Everything made from scratch. Never had a bad meal here.

Here is the deal: Sam and his band of merry lunatics make everything by hand (except the pitas).  He brings in huge bags of beans and bushels of vegetables, and makes enough falafel, hummus, and kabobs to feed the lunch hour army that storms the poor jewelers mall where this true gem is hidden. The food they create is delicious and some of the options on the menu should be about twice the price that they currently are.  It's not uncommon for me to eat here 3-4 times a week, because I know that I can't find the same value or quality for the price anywhere else. It's also not uncommon for your food to be ready for you before you've gotten your change back from the cashier.  These people are serious about what they do, and it shows.

Have you ever wanted falafel and a gold watch? How about chicken kabob and diamond earrings?  You can have this and more at Oasis. The small food counter is located at the back of a jewelry store. This is a truly unique Chicago experience.  The falafel, lamb kabob, chicken shwarma, and hummus are all quite good. I've never sampled anything from the jewelry store, however.

I got sick of this place only because I ate it so much, but for the cost and the over all weirdness of it being in the back of a jewelry shop, I give this an a-ok rating.  Vegetarian plate under $5 , with extra pita for $.25? Yes please.
Oasis is on our family's list for: near the train healthy with plenty of vegetarian options  very reasonable prices quick easy to carry and eat while walking.

One of my favorite restaurants in all of Chicago.  The food is fantastic, fresh, authentic.  I used to work just around the corner and my favorite lunch was their soups - fresh every day and so flavorful.  The falafel is great, the kabobs, every thing on the menu is great.  And beyond being fantastic - it's extremely affordable.  The fact that it's in the Jewelry Mall makes it even more fun - I love to take visitors here.

How did I just find out about this place?!  It's outstanding.  I have never been a huge falafel fan, but the stuff they sell here it great.  I ordered the combination plate for $7 and it came with 3 falafel, 5 pieces of ground lamb/beef kefta, a ton of rice,  veggies, cucumbers, baba ganouj, tahini, hot sauce and a piece of warm soft pita.  Need I say more?  It was all quite tasty, and at that price, you couldn't do better.

Its so weird that this place is located at the back of a jewelery store!!! If they didnt have the "Oasis Cafe" sign out front, we would have been scratching our heads trying to figure out where the place was located! The food was definitely good. I'm not a kabob fan, but we had the lamb kabob and it was extremely tender, moist, and flavorful. Not your typical kabob because it was not on a stick and not dry. Their hummus is extremely fresh. The lentil soup tasted great too. Prices here are very affordable. Lots of seating upstairs and downstairs. The place is air conditioned too. AWESOME!!!! Oh, and they take credit cards! Yipee!
Great hole in the wall with great prices. My mother lives nearby and recommended it for our research group while in town for a conference. Our whole group was happy with their meal.

I thought it was a joke - a Mediterranean place inside a jewelry shop? YEP, it's true folks. Just walk right pass all those sparkly goodies and head towards yummy food. They have daily specials and I ended up getting that when I got there which was the Moroccan couscous with chicken shawarma. The chicken was really good and not dry at all. The couscous I was not too fond of, but with the pita and all the other goodies on my styrofoam plate I was definitely stuffed. All for under $6 or 7 dollars. HELL YEAHHH. It's a bit far from my office though so maybe on special occasions I'll reunite with the falafel and plastic-ware here.

Wowzers, that was a yummy meal. And speaking as a reformed picky eater, that really means something.  Coming from Ohio, things that seem so standard now (sushi, Thai, Indian) were once considered "exotic" and to be avoided at all costs. Four years later, my palate has expanded along with my waistline and I no longer live in fear of new cuisines. Thank goodness, or else I would've missed out on Oasis Cafe.  Is it crazy that this place is located in the back of a jewelry store? Yes. But the food is also crazy delicious. I ordered the chicken schwarma with hummus and it was $7.50 for the whole thing. The portions were HUGE. I couldn't finish it all, even though I wanted to. The chicken was tender and well-seasoned, the bed of hummus is laid on provided enough flavor, but not so much that it overwhelmed the chicken. I tried their "hot sauce" but I emplore you to proceed with caution as it will immediately clear out your sinuses. After trying a bite of someones falafel, the deal was sealed. I will definitely be back and continue my foray into Mediterranean cuisine.

Meh. After growing up eating Mediterranean cuisine in Dearborn, MI this place is seriously lacking. The falafel was a little too bland for me. I've been spoiled by Taza. And I just can't shake the fact that I'm eating in the back of a watch store on my lunch hour. Would make for a good SNL skit though. Oasis is the new Billy Goat. And who has samples of food they don't sell on the counter for you to try? Next.

It's a toss up for me between Taza and Oasis Cafe for best Mediterranean in the loop but Oasis is closer to where I work so I know it much more intimately.  All the sandwiches are awesome and the Chicken Napoli is the hands down best dish but it's only available on Wednesday.  Funny to walk through the jewelry mall the first time also, always some characters in there...

Love the food, but has anyone else noticed a lot of attitude with the employees lately?  I'm writing this while enjoying a Chicken Shawarma I got for lunch.  Both the woman at the counter and the gentleman serving up the food (who I've always assumed was the manager) could not have been more rude.  Does asking for hot sauce warrant slamming it down on the counter so hard that it opens the container?  The woman behind me in line paid for her soup with a credit card and you would think she slapped the cashier.   I'll be back, it's one of my favorite lunch spots in the Loop, but come one guys.  You have a great product, how about we work on the attitude? Update: Back today for lunch and everyone was happy as a clam.  Maybe I just caught them on a few consecutive bad days?  I know I have them too.

I have been to this location 3 times and have tried different dishes each time. Before my last experience, I would have said 4 stars, but I thought that my couscous special dish was very oily and bland, and severely lacked the vegetables that were promised.  The location in the back of Jeweler's Mart makes this place seem like a hidden gem. On my first visit 2 years ago, I felt like I had stumbled upon a hidden secret of Chicago. It still seems very humble in its decor, but it has been packed with people every time that I've visited since. I think an upgrade of tables or decor (new tiles, perhaps?) would help the place, since it lacks the luxury of having windows or an easily accessible entrance. The vegetarian sampler plate is good but small in portion for the price. I wish that I had a picture of it to show the small quantity. I don't actively seek out large portions of food, but I left feeling slightly hungry. It consisted of 2 falafels balls, one piece of pita bread, side of hummus and baba ganouj, and two stuffed grape leaves. Certainly a good sampling of vegetarian Lebanese fare, but I could've benefited from another falafel ball.

The appeal of this place, for me, is solely based on the fact that it resides in the back of a store on Jeweler's Row.  I ordered the spinach pie special. The spinach pie consisted of a piece of pita type bread folded over and filled with cooked spinach and sprinkled with zatyr. It's like zatyr bread with spinach. But I really just wanted a spinach pie. One of my sides was the babaghanoush, which was overpowered with the flavor of smoke and lemon juice. Between the tartness of the zatyr, the lemony babaghanoush, and the pickled beets, I was on acidity overload from this meal. Unfortunately, the only thing to balance it out was falafal that was very dry and bland. The condiment with the meal had the flavor of tahini but the consistency of water. Why do places do this? The consistency of any condiment, sauce, or chutney is as important as it's flavor, and serving these watery substances is just wrong. I don't recall what I've had in previous visits, except once I had Foul, something analogous to hummus but made with fava beans. I'm not sure w  I will certainly give this place another try, because on the surface it seems like a place I should love. I just wish the food was a little better.

I hate to leave this review, because I really don't want more people to know about this place. I've been coming here for a few months now. On my first visit, I ordered a falafel sandwich and was so satisfied that I've not yet once veered from this tradition. At least once a week, I visit Oasis Cafe for a falafel sandwich. With this order, I can eat in the Loop for under five dollars. Yes, read that again. Eat in the Loop for under five dollars. The other dishes look delicious. The kabob plates, in particular, are huge, healthy, and tasty-looking. But all I really need is a handful of falafel goodness to keep me going for the rest of the day, and to keep some greenbacks in my wallet. The location only helps this restaurant. I love ducking into this jewelry mall, with only the intention of ordering a sandwich. It feels like I'm on to a secret that only a few hundred other people know. Also, the food is great and, for the most part, the service has been top-notch. Nothing fancy, mind you -- you are ordering at a counter and taking your own food to a table via plastic tray. But, they are efficient and quick and move people through the long line as fast as possible.  Hooray for Oasis Cafe!

Great food, good prices, quick service (particularly on the Falafel) and a fair amount of seating. The Falafel sandwich is large and tasty, the lentil soup is great, the Lamb Kafta is a huge meal as is the Chicken Shawarma on a bed of hummus. I haven't had a bad thing yet. Bumping up to five stars because it is a good deal too. There aren't enough affordable independent lunch places in the loop. If you're way further south, try BenjYehuda.

Since I was at the Palmer House for a conference, I decided to hop over to Oasis Cafe and check it out.  I'm really glad I did. Tucked in the back of a jewelry mall, this little cafe serves up some of the tastiest Middle eastern food I've ever had.  I had the hummus plate with lamb, and it was a complete hit. The hummus is unique - smoother than the norm and the heavy use of tahini hides any bitterness.  It definitely had a clear nutty flavor that I really liked. The lamb was extraordinarily well spiced, with lots of cinnamon and nutmeg that complemented the nutty hummus really well.  It was perfectly grilled, fork-tender, and juicy. For $6.95, how the heck can you go wrong?  You can't.  I'll definitely go back next year.

SO GREAT. In a world where finding some place in the loop to eat that is worthwhile is difficult, Oasis helps us all get through that work week. I love walking through the jewelry store to the back. Its really quick, and completely affordable, NOT TO MENTION super tasty.  Sometimes it can get a long line, but there really isn't anything wrong with that because once you order the food comes out fast. LOVE the falafel, their tahini & whatever that hot sauce is. ALSO, the crispy, crunchy pita bits that they place on the counter for you to grab. Not exactly sure when or how frequent they place them out, but when they are there, its like another perk for my coworkers and I. When we decide we are going there for lunch, it honestly makes an otherwise dreary workday better.
Once the novelty of this lunch spot being in the back of a jewerly mall wears off, the food turns out to be just 'ok'.

been going here for years because there's no complaints about the food whatsoever, they're quick, it's super close to work and you can't beat the $1 soup deal! the problem lately are these fucking art school kids and i guess i'd call them hipsters flocking over during lunch time. as a courtesy to the customers they have these amazing grilled pita 'chips' at the front counter. any normal individual would take one and move one, but these kids have no idea what consideration is. they just sit there and grab handfuls holding up the line and keep going back. it's almost getting to the point where i might have to stop going :(  just because it's a Mediterranean joint doesn't mean you automatically have ownership of it. get it in your heads.

I no longer work on the row (everyone KNOWS Steve Quick Jeweler is THE jeweler to go to!!) but I still frequent Oasis Cafe when I am conducting bidness in the area. The Hummos with Meat plate is my go-to order at this joint.  The hummos (you say hummos, I say hummus, lets call the whole thing off..) has a nice nutty/tahini flavor and the chicken has a wonderfully complex taste.  A piece of pita and some cucumber and tomato (you say tomato, I say...uh..sorry..just kidding) round out the plate for some serious lunching. The jewelry booths that line the walk back to the cafe are interesting to say the least.  I mean, who buys jewelry at these places?  They remind me of mall kiosks, but I digress, and you know where to go if you need jewels anyway, right?  Promote yourself much, Sarah B.?  ;) Anywho, all you need to know is that hidden deep in the dark depths of a shady jewelry mall is some seriously delicious Mediterranean grub.  Good grub that is convenient and cheap.  Go!

Yum yum yum yum!!! Everyone I work with has been raving about this place & everything they brought back always smelled incredible so I had to go check it out.  I got the combination platter which had rice, chicken kabob, baba ganoush, and falafel.  I was so full by the end I could barely move, and it was only $6.99!  I also tried the beef platter that my friend got, it was so well seasoned, I'm definitely getting that next time.  I was so charmed by the fact that Oasis is in the back of a jewelry store, adds character and makes me feel like I know a secret, haha!

Best Meditteranean/Arabic food place in Chicago Hands Down. Thier Shawarma is really good. Felafel is solid and the kebab sandwiches are good.  I would like it if they made the Sandwiches in a more authentic pita (More like a wrap - I think you only get them like that in the Middle-East/Medditeranian region) I can probably get lunch from here everyday of the week.

There's absolutely nothing I can picked on at Oasis Cafe. NADA! First day at my new job and instead of hearing about the company culture/ training needed / bagel day, I hear about a somewhat obscure Mediterranean restaurant that's hidden at the back of a Watch store, boasting the best falafel in downtown. I've gotta check this out!  That's how my Mediterranean food addiction began. Going to Oasis Cafe is always an adventure & treat for out-of-towners, shooting you puzzled looks as you opened the door to the watch store with hawker style mini-stands selling Rolex & other assortment of gold watchers.  "There's food in here? " they ask, oOooooh little do they know about the magical kingdom that beholds them! For the vegetarians / health-conscious friends, point them to the direction of Falafel pita sandwich & a side of stuffed Grape Leaves.  The sandwich comes filled with crunchy falafels, fresh cucumber & tomato slices, and hummus!  The stuffed Grape leaves are juicy and perfect sized to pop-in-your mouth!  For the meat lovers, point them to the direction of Chicken Shawarma pita sandwiches or, my personal favorite, their Tuesday Special:  Moroccan Chicken!  The shawarma overflows from the pita, perfectly grilled and blend of fat & thin meat, with hummus/ tahini to moisten the meal!    But the Moroccan Chicken is what I dream of every Tuesday... a HUGE meal with plenty of rice, 2 baked potatoes, and typically chicken breast + drumstick. I've never had chicken so perfectly tender, juicy, and marinated with fragrant spices!  I am not kidding when I tell ya that I can make 2 solid meals out of the special....!!  With all the good reviews Oasis Cafe has garnered, it's about time for you to track down this gem and try it for yourself! Don't forget to bring your friends, I promise you'll score extra favors ;)

Had to update this review and make it 5 stars.  I went again today to find myself in the back of a line stretching halfway through the jewelry store.  As it turns out, I was in line for maybe 4 minutes tops and the food was outstanding! This place is amazing.  Oh, get the hot sauce if you're into that type of thing.  It's some of the best I've had.

Ah!  Delicious!  My sister and I went as much for the kitsch as we did for the food, and were not disappointed on either account!  The restaurant is a quick affair at the end of a long jewelry store, which oddly enough evokes a memory of eating in a traditional souq.  Very bare bones (deli style) service, but the food is first rate!  Hands down best falafel I have been able to sample so far, despite searching several countries including Israel for adequate samples.  I wish I saw the sandwich board for the daily specials before I ordered, BUT my combination platter (baba ghanoush, beef kebab, pita, and rice) was nowhere near being disappointing.  I will be coming back with out of town guests in order to show off Chicago's metropolitan flair and to pretend my own 'insider's view' of the city.

Meh is the perfect way to describe it.  We went there around 1, wanted to get the special, but the guy in front of us got the last one! GRR!!! It's not really anyone's fault, maybe the special is THAT delicious! Anyway, I got the chicken shwarma, and thought that it was pretty bland. I still ate it, don't get me wrong, but thought it was lacking in seasoning. The place is great for the price, but I think I like things to be a little more flavorful.
dont let the location fool you.  you cant beat the food here, top notch quality, tasty, and cheap....if you like middle eastern / medeteranian food this is the spot hands down...

And the award for the "Best Cheap Lunch Spot with Flair" goes to Oasis Cafe!   I've had Oasis' takeout menu on my menu caddy here at work for months now (somebody must've passed it out to me as I was walking by).  However, I have never ventured in until today...and I am so glad I did!!!  The falafel with the tahini sauce was the best I've had in the city so far and the grape leaves actually had flavor to it.   I just want to say thanks for sharing your tastes with us Oasis; I'll be back tomorrow and I'm sure many more times to come!!

It took me a little while to find you again, but you're back where you always should have been and serving the hands down best falafel in the city...people it's no joke, all of your other falafel joints need to step off. Bother with the chicken specials if you must, try the lamb kifta (it reminds me of the disaster sausage at Sarkis) But the $4 falafel is a gawd damn home run
Still the jam.  Just tried their Lentil soup, pretty bada$$. Sandwich and a huge bowl of soup for under $6 in the Loop. Pretty tough to beat.

Random, random, RANDOM restaurant!  I almost didn't believe my friend when she said there was a Medi cafe at the back of the Wabash Jewelers...SO strange...like what was the business plan there? Has it always been in the Jewelers or is that like a side business for them??  Anyways, we went for lunch today and it was alright.  I got a falafel sammie, which is my standard comparison for Medi food, and it was good enough, but hard to eat.  The falafel was not mashed up, the cucumbers and tomatoes were cut in whole chunks, and you can't order what you like on the sammie...it comes out pre-prepared before you even finish paying. At every other Medi lunch spot, i can see them making my sammie and ask for extra sauce, a little of this, a little of that, etc.  Not at Oasis - only got tahini sauce on it and not very much (even w/the extra side of sauce it was still not enough).  I tried lentil soup for the first time (it was only $1 extra) and it was ok i suppose although it came out SCALDING hot and burnt my tongue (in a styrofoam cup) and it didn't have much flavor.  Seriously needed some salt and pepper.  So all this plus a diet Coke for $6.44 - quite the bargain - but nonetheless, there are several other Medi lunch spots with 10xs better atmosphere that i like a lot more than this one.

Outstanding choice!  I've been to several Mediterranean places downtown, but this one seems to be at the top of my list now.  I went with a group of 5 others and we ordered a variety of dishes: lentil soup, chicken shawarma (with rice and with hummus), hummus plate and the Wabash special.  It was the first time there for all 6 of us, and each of us loved our dishes.  The hummus was just right - not too much tahini or oil, the lentil soup was perfect, and within 15 minutes, the plates were clean.  I ate till I was full and still took home a good amount of hummus that I'll eat for lunch tomorrow.  The falafel were just right - not too dry or greasy.  Although the owner at Taza is super friendly and always has samples, this place is just as great.  Reasonable prices for great food.  This is a "cafe" we'll come back to frequently.

This place is fantastic.  The flavor in the hummus is out of this world, chicken has a ton of flavor, service is fast.  I don't know what else you would ask for....well you might ask for a different location.  Although,  who doesn't like walking through a jewelery store to get to lunch?

How to serve good hummos to your guests at home: 1) Go to the Oasis Cafe and buy a large order of hummos to go. 2) Take it home. 3 )Remove the pita and raw vegetables and eat them; call it lunch. 4) Add a bit of garlic if you like your hummos really garlicky. 5) Refrigerate until guests arrive and try not to eat it before they show up. You will have about a pint of the most buttery smooth hummos you ever tasted.

Apparently this place likes to play "musical locations" because they're now back in the jewelry store.  Yeah it's award to walk through the jewelery section to get there -- just make sure not to bring your girlfriend with so that she doesn't come up with things for you to buy her ;)!  So anyway, this place is small but we had no problem finding seating (during the busy lunch hour on a weekday).  I really liked my falafel sandwich!  In order to make it Vegan, simply ask them to not use the white sauce (which contains yogurt) and have them put hummus on it instead (YUM!).  My bf got the vegetarian combo and that was very delish as well!  Overall I think this is a great lunch option for those that work in the loop (including Vegans).

Woohoo! As good as it gets!! That's right, yelp, your cheesy rating header took the words right outta my mouth. I LOVE HELLA RANDOM PLACES LIKE THIS!! First off, it's located at the back of a Jewerly Mart circa 1973 that is actually bussling and thriving and kinda reminds me of the Jefferson's, even though I never really watched that show, so that's awesome. You can get blasted by bling AND contemplate your future rings needs?! WIN! Of course, I'm far too socially-conscious and morally superior to wear those blood diamonds (boo! hiss!), but don't let such concerns weigh you down (gurl, is that a PINK diamond?!?! a la J Lo and Ben 2003? that's what i'm talkin' about!!).  Next, the food is actually DELICIOUS! what, what! no air, no light, no windows, no cross-ventilation, and your food is still the bomb?! YOU WIN, Oasis Cafe!! YOU WIN! I had the falafel sandwich and while not quite as tasty as Taza's, it's pretty damn close and that Tahini sauce is some kinda wonderful and that hot sauce is like whoa. so....GO! whatcha waitin' for willis?! (shit! i'm getting all my shows mixed up! is that the robot girl?!)

I love going on urban safaris! What i mean by that is I like trying to go explore for places I have never been to. I decided that I was going to find some hummus and actually never knew of a Greek/Lebanese/Mediterranean restaurant in the Loop. So I began my journey. Under an EL and I find myself in a jewlers row jungle. Then I see a sign saying Oasis Cafe... Well I actually couldnt find it.... WHY? The cafe is in the back of a jewelry mall... I thought that was rather unique. So I successfully completed my safari.  The hummus was quite good, but I wouldn't say it sticks out as a top 5 hummus. An ok price tag on the food, and it was quite packed around lunch time.  I will have to go back and get the gyro... So far so good on this urban safari.
We both had the mixed lamb plate - absolutely amazing but so much food. Kind of hilarious that it's instead of a jewelry store.

I'd give them 4.5 stars if I could.  I called in my order (Falafel Plate) and I was able to bypass the long line, and pay for it.   The whole transaction was maybe 75 seconds - and that's because I bought a drink.   I'm not a heavy falafel eater, so I can't tell if this is great or average... but it satisfied my omnivorous taste buds.   Reasonably priced, good food, fast, and courteous service.   I'd have preferred the falafel plate to come on a bed of rice with a bit of lettuce, as opposed to an entire bed of shredded lettuce/cabbage.

I've been telling myself that I need to stop giving 5-star reviews. But I'm a stickler for value, and I just had one of the top 5 falafel sandwiches of my life (certainly of Chicago) for $4. This is as good as it gets. The location of this place is hilarious - if it weren't for Yelp I would never have found it. Best way to find it is to go by address - go to 21 N Wabash and look in the window, and walk to the back of the creepy jewelery store, and there it is. Staff was super friendly - what's more, they take credit cards, even for small purchases, which I don't find often for small places like this.  I've been to Taza, and my sandwich rivaled it. The falafel at Taza was better, but here the tahini, of all things, was what made the sandwich. I've never had tahini that was anything other than a moisture adding condiment - this stuff was rich and flavorful and you could taste the sesame seed flavor in it. This was an excellent sandwich - lots of fresh cucumber and plenty of falafel, good to the last bite, and stuffed to the brim. I'm veeery full right now. I work on hourly wage in an office on Michigan, so if I take more than 15 minutes for lunch, I start losing money. I have sampled, therefore, every obvious restaurant around Madison and Wabash about 6 billion times. This place is cheaper than Quiznos, cheaper than Starbucks, cheaper than Chipotle, cheaper than Panda Express, cheaper than Jimmy Johns and is something actually tasty and special.  Go here. go here now.

Awesome food. Mmmm I love thier grape leaves. I never liked them until I had them here. They have great vegatable soup, I wish mine would turn out as good when I make it at home. The baba Ganouj is also great. I think its WAY better than Sultans Market & less mayonaisey then Tabouns. Theres lots of meat selections, the kaftka looked good but I haven't tried it.  This is a very healthy place to eat. No processed meats or nitrates, tons of whole vegatables, no high fructose corn syrup or preservatives and LOTS of all natural flavor.

I agree with everyone who enjoyed the Falafel. It was priced just right and very well made. I wasn't able to finish the entire sandwich so I took it home. Reheated very well! always a good thing in my book. I love that you walk through the jewelry to get to the restaurant. Such a find! I can't wait to try some of their daily specials. The Lamb special on Wed looked very good.

Falafel is so so so sooooooo good. Awesome prices too! So glad I found this place on Yelp and finally got to try it out. Looking forward to going back and trying out their specials. I really wanted the stuffed chicken breast they had on special the day I went but by 12:45pm they were all out of it! Bummer.
I lovvvved the falafel and the pricing was just right! Weird location made it even better. It's how "real" restaurants should be.

Wow, stilll can't get over the weird location. So of course when I heard about this place I had to check it out.  Good thing they had a sign in front of the building, otherwise I wouldn't been walking around confused longer. The place is pretty hot, since it's kinda located in an alcove.   I ordered the chicken schwarma plate over hummus.  Bad idea; I dont' like the hummus touching the chicken.  I personally don't think they go too well together.  The chicken was pretty good as was the hummus.   The best thing in my eyes was the hot sauce.  Y'know that red hot sauce all the Middle Eastern places serve?  This place had the best by far.  Better than Pita Express and Tazas.  It was a rich red color, and very thick comparatively.  Had a nice deep, full flavor.   With a drink, the meal came out to 9 bucks.  A little pricey ~$1-2 more than the average place, I would say. They have free pieces of crisped/burnt pita ends chililng on the counter.  Considering how much hummus they give you, not a bad idea to grab a few pretty tasty. For all you water drinkers, they have small cups next to the pop machine.   *gaaaah* I almost said 'soda,' gotta stop hanging out with east coast people.  In summary: Ambience:  very weird and interesting Food:  Good, but not stellar; hot sauce stands out Value:  a little pricey Overall:  cool place to check out...I mean c'mon...the location!

Yummers! The shwarma sammich is nice and tasty, and there was a ton of chicken. And it dips nicely into my ginormous side of hummus. It was a teensy bit pricey at $9, but i have enough hummus for a snack later, so I'm ok with that. Oh, and I called in my order and they had it waiting for me and rang me up super quick...in and out and scoping out ugly gold earrings in less than a minute!
Falafel was excellent, but the shish kabob meat was full of gristle.  Chicken was tasty.  Would go back but probably will stick to falafel.

It seems kind of shady that you have to walk to the back of a jewelery store to get to this place, but it's worth it. I would feel less comfortable buying jewelery in the back of a falafel stand.  The falafel was good, and made fresh as I waited. There were lots of veggie items on the menu as well as a few meat dishes.  There are a few tables next to the stand so you can watch people trying on pinkie rings or asking how much they can get for a slightly used engagement ring.

Yum, Yum, YUM.   I don't know about the rest of you, but most days I'd much rather pack some leftovers or a tasty sammie for lunch than spend $10 at one of the Loop's poor excuses for a lunch place.  With a few exceptions. Enter Oasis Cafe. Located at the back of the Jewelry Mart on Wabash, you'd hardly know it existed (unless, like moi,  your husband-to-be loves watches and works across the street).  We popped in yesterday to get some food to-go and dine in Millenium Park since it was such a gorgeous day.  For $17 we got a TON of food.  I had the veggie combo, which included: hummus, baba ganoush, 3 generous sized falafel balls, pita, stuffed grape leaves and salad.  I'd venture to say one of the best falafel in the city.  Nick got the shish kebab combo, which also came with hummus and baba ganoush and pita.  The meat was well seasoned and tasty, and the accompanying rice had a nice cinnamon-spice taste to it.  Wash it down with a diet Coke and some baklava and you have yourself a fantastic lunch for 2, all for $17. I will definitely return to Oasis Cafe for more Middle-Eastern goodness in the Loop.  Spice up your lunch hour a little and check it out!
