been coming here for about 5 years now, which i guess says it all.  this place is rad. and yes, the fact that it is in the back of the wabash jewelers mall makes it even more rad.  why? because if you own and break as much jewelry as i do (can't stop throwing it in the bottom of my enormous purse), you can not only get lunch, you can also take your earrings and necklaces to get fixed at the jewelry repair stall in the back.  my favorites are the harissa soup, the falafel sandwich with hummus and the chicken schwarma plate.  if you like a bit of spice, don't forget to ask for a container of homemade hot sauce.  if they sold it in tubs, i would buy it for home.

The fact that it's in the back of a legit jewelry store gives this place an automatic three stars. The food is legit as well. Started with the stuffed grape leaves which were nice and served with some well marinated veggies. Next up was the chicken kebab sandwich, filled with TONS of perfectly marinated chicken and just enough veggies and sauce. The place was also packed, so the secret is out, good for them, but not so good if you are in a hurry...

any mediterranean cafe hidden within a large and dated jewelry store gets my vote. oh, and the food is good too which is slightly important. my two tips would be to make sure you don't overlook the hot sauce and PLEASE get a side of the pickled turnip to mix into your meal whichever way you like.

I have eaten here twice in as many weeks.  They are fast, fresh, and tasty.  I had the Falafel platter first, then the sandwich.  The Sandwich is negligibly less food than the platter, yet it's assembled by a pro, so that helps, and it's a dollar cheaper.  It's at the back of the Jeweler's mall.  A great little place in a weird location.  I'll definitely be back to try a meat dish.

I can say that this is my favorite lunch place in the entire loop. The owner is great and he often will give out free dessert. The falafel sandwich is great and with a cup of soup only comes to $5.50 how can you say no to that... I sure can't.

first off: if you're looking for falafel, i think the falafel here is just ok.  not many great falafel options in this part of the loop, as far as i know, so maybe try taza or brian's juice bar? (EDIT: 8/4/2009. I've reconsidered, the falafel here can be pretty good.) lentil soup is very tasty. service is friendly.  i most highly want to recommend the specials on tues, wed and fri. if i hit oasis on a friday i always get the vegetarian cous cous. i haven't been there on a tuesday for awhile, but i used to regularly enjoy the moroccan chicken plate. wednesday is my favorite special, kushari w/grilled lamb.  why not take your lunch tray upstairs for a bit of privacy and birds-eye view of the jewelry gallery?

I miss the good Mediterranean food that I used to get in the East Loop because my work 'hood has crap. Good thing we all go to drs over there or I'd be totally deprived.  Whenever one of us heads to this part of downtown, it's either here or Brian's.  I choose Brian's, my counterpart chooses Oasis.  Either one rocks, but I think that Brian's has better hummus and grape leaves and a better selection of foods.  HOWEVER, the food here is REALLY good and their falafel is incredibly fresh.  I definitely won't knock this place for anything other than the fact that it's not as good as Brian's in comparison.

I felt rushed to order more than I wanted because it was so crowded during the lunch hour...Not helpful at all--and the tabouleh was the worst tabouleh that I ever had...Barely any parsley filled with mostly iceberg lettuce and  a large piece of onion as well as too lemony...I was convinced to order a large when I wanted a small and was really disappointed that it was not just terrible but disgusting... When I told them that it was bad the woman and man behind the counter said, "That's what you ordered"... I say se la vie.... I threw out my meal and can guarantee that I will never be returning to that place again...Thanks for my ongoing trips to Pita Inn I feel grateful that I have great alternatives.... Deerfield

Well, this review is more for the vegetarian food (didn't even try the falafels) so not sure how representative of the full menu it is...  Had the Greek Salad, which was 80% lettuce and 20% combo of cucumber-tomato-feta. Not really what I was hoping for! My friend had the grapeleaves and didn't enjoy them much either... Maybe it's just more of a meat place and do a much better job there? Not good-tasting for vegetarians though, even though the menu is vegetarian-friendly!
A really great and close option.  The meat and vegetables are always high quality for the money.  well prepared and hummus is good.  6.50 for a shwarma plate.

The Loop Lunch Saga continues with... Oasis Cafe!  This little gem is indeed hidden in the back of a jewelry store. I personally love both shiny things and yummy food, so you know where this is going!  I had the Moroccan chicken special and an IBC rootbeer. It seemed a little pricey when the girl rang up $10, but when I picked up my to go box and my arm involuntarily sank under it's weight, I knew every thing was going to be all right.   I sat on a blanket in the park feasting on juicy chicken (4 pieces! I only ate 2), savory rice, and an eclectic mix of veggies. It was totally delicious and provide two whole meals (I finished off the leftovers just hours ago.) I will definitely be going back when it's nice again and the picnic bug bites.

So I tried going to the location they moved to 3 weeks ago and thought they went out of business. Then today I walked by their old location in back of the jewelry store and saw the sign. It was just shy of 11am and I wasn't even that hungry yet. I was heading up north and had to go in and eat lunch anyway. It's been too long. The new space is a huge improvement. Opted for the mixed combo of falafel, baba ganouch, and meat of my choice. I choose chicken shwarma(usually have kefta kabab). It was huge and spot on. Also have great hummus and lentil soup. And the daily specials are always tasty and unique. Great bargain as well for downtown. So if you ever see a sign for this place outside a brightly lit jewelry store, walk in and keep going past the colorful bunch of jewelers to some of the best middle eastern food in town.

I love this place! I happened to run into it randomly years ago. When i was going to DePaul, I used to go there for lunch all the time. I've tried everything on the menu and everything has been good so far. I think i'm going to go there for lunch today! :)

Apparently this place has moved around a bit. BUt just so you know it is at the back of the hilarious Wabash Jewelers Mall. And it is 21 N. Wabash not 17 S. Wabash or whatever Yelp has it listed as.  I got the shis kebab platter and it was super awesome! Great job! The meat was tender and not too chewy. The rice, beans and humus were all great enhancers. The pita bread was light and fluffy. I got tons of food for about $6.50.  MMMMmmmm!  I will definitely be back! I want to go Thursday fir the Wabash Combo platter...

Want to munch on some falafel while shopping for an engagement ring?  This is your spot.   Oasis is without a doubt the best middle eastern food I've ever eaten inside a jewelry store.  Would I make a special trip out here?  Hell to the no.  But it is a good lunch alternative to Chipotle, Panda Express, Jimmy Johns, etc.

Took me 2 days to find it but I did, thanks to saleem! I ordered the Monday - Wabash Special - some kinda of chicken in phyllo dough. Even though it was Thursday they recommended it and said I would love it. I substituted the Foul for Tabbouleh in the combo with no problems.  Everything was GREAT except the tabbouleh, which was a bit too salty for me. Total was about $7 and some change so not too bad. I like it and I will be back!

The Best Food So Far (BFSF) ... Try this meal (Steak, Chicken Kabab, Rice, Hummos, Tabbouleh). Just go there and ask for this exact meal and then write me back if you loved it and BELIEVE ME YOU WILL. I can not wait till tomorrow comes so I can go there for Lunch. ;-)
The food is fabulous, it's cheap and the staff is soooo nice.  It's one of the few places in the loop that isn't a chain, so refreshing.

Went there for lunch today. Although the line was long, I got my food fairly quickly. The falafel is cooked to perfection, at least for me. A falafel sandwich is $4..a falafel platter is $5. Honestly, I probably wouldn't order anything else.

The best part about this place is walking through the half-empty jewelry store before you can order your food at the counter. Then as you are sitting down to eat your food you get to listen to the sounds of drills and sanders as a variety of jewelry is being repaired.  I ordered the Monday Special or Wabash Mixed Combo - it is Moroccan chicken Pastilla*(*fillo dough stuffed with chicken, carrot, green pepper, and onions) served with Hummus and Falafel for only $6.99. It was was pretty good and a lot cheaper then a burger I had a few days later. The Moroccan chicken Pastilla which is almost like a mini burrito was great. If was something I hadn't had before so it was a nice change of pace. The falafel was ok... but I think Jaffa Bagels makes some better ones. If you're just looking for Falafels in the loop check out Jaffa Bagels. But if you're looking for some other Middle Eastern eats they Oasis Cafe is a perfect stop in the loop.

Lordy. Oasis. You can't stop moving. Probably the best middle eastern option downtown. At least the food was consistently mediocre. Hummus was pas mal- not bad. It ain't spectacular, if you find yourself in Skokieland, go to Pita Inn on Dempster Ave. Their food is divine.  Oasis was always around and when you wanted something other than 'merican fat foods or french soup- Oasis was always around the corner.  It was a staple of my time at the institute. Tried and true.

Back in the jewelry mall!  Yay!!  And they've spiffed things up a bit -- very fancy  new kitchen and counter.  The falafel seemed a little smaller, though, so I'm keeping Oasis at the status quo four stars.
A must go experience. The food is pretty good, (though the shwarma pita isn't heated on a press) but the fact that you're walking through a semi seedy Jeweler shop--even better.
a true hidden gem....tucked away inside a jewelry store!! the second best chicken schwarma sandwich next to Sultans Market.....

So it took me a while to actually find the place (it's in this cafeteria inside of a building), but it was worth the while. The falafel was great (I've eaten the sandwich and the platter), and the price was right, especially considering how huge the portion was! It's also great to see vegetarian and vegan options in the loop that aren't sub par to the rest of the menu. I think its a good place for someone new to falafel to try, I've brought with me friends that have never eaten this type of food, and they were hooked.

Okay, this places is so cool!  I wasn't sure if I was in the right place having stepped into a Jewelry store and wandering towards the back of the place, but there it was!  Right there in the very back, a tiny little quaint Falafel shop!  I was watering at the mouth.  There were about six little tables or so set up in front of the food 'stand' with people chowing down quietly on the yummy good stuff which led me to believe, this place has got to have some tasty food if people would wander into a Jewelry store for some food!  So, I ordered the Falafel sandwich and a side of hummus and pita for the folks back at my office and was in and out in a matter of minutes.  Those guys are fast!  I got back to my desk and started to stuff my face.  OMGOSH, YUMMY!  I love Falafel and this was some good stuff.  So fresh and tasty and authentic.  Plus, the hummus was a hit with everyone else at my office so it's definitely a winner!  I will be headed back REGULARLY, for sure!  YEA. You must go.

So I got the falafel sandwich (urged by my bf and fellow yelpers) and a soda for $6.00! I couldn't believe how cheap it was, especially since I've been paying close to $10 for lunch here in the loop. I liked the sandwich and the hot sauce that came with it. I'm really interested in trying their other sandwiches since I'm not a HUGE falafel fan. I'm giving it three stars for now since the sandwich was good, but not my favorite. I will change it once I taste something else if necessary :) If you're looking for something filling, healthy (at least that's what I'm telling myself), and cheap-Oasis Cafe just be a perfect fit! Oh, and my sandwich was ready just as I was finished putting my money into my wallet. It's fast and cheap-who could ask for more? **UPDATE: I added the Hummos to my sandwich and it was delicious! It was way more filling and tender this way. The only downside is that my pita started falling apart towards the end of the sandwich. Bummer.

Good lord, this place is tasty. Everything was perfectly spiced (but not hot-spicy), filling and satisfying.  The hummos was perfect, the vegetables were fresh, the meat was tasty and the pita was warm and soft, not stale at all. It's in an odd location in the back of a jewelry mall, but that doesn't matter because there's upstairs seating and some tables and chairs downstairs.  I highly recommend it.

Absolutely no pretense, absolutely fantastic food. I got their special of the day and loved everything on my plate.  The portions were perfect and the price was pretty good for the location. Go get yourself a nice guido pinky ring and then treat yourself to falafel.

This place embodies "character'. Located in a foodcourt under the tracks on Wabash, the Oasis Cafe is truly an oasis of decency in a grimy improbable food court. I've never seen a food court attached to nothing, but this place has great shwarma and falafel. Kind of weirdly lit and 80's looking, though.
Some of the best food in one of the most depressing food courts. The chicken is always delicious. but the atmosphere is terrible.
meh. go to taza if you've got the time.

No longer in the jewelers building Oasis moved into a small food court. I'd recommend getting in and getting out, the food court place is depressing. Last time i ate Oasis food was like 6 years ago! These people have been around forever man, WTF?! The falafel is probably the best in the loop. Perfectly moist if lacking a bit of flavor. The falafel sandwich is hefty and chock fulla falafel. No need for hummus to moisten things up, the falafel stand on their own. ETA: Awesome Veggie combo!

How many of you are allergic to raw tomatoes?  Probably none, but I am and I specifically asked for food with no tomatoes. Needless to say I did not get my wish. I am giving it three stars though in hopes of increasing the stars next time I get to go again. (maybe tomorrow) I order the stuffed chicken and tried just a little bit.  Oh, it was so good, but I had to throw it out because of the tomatoe part. Everyone else who ordered the food absolutely loved it though and I can say that the souvlaki was really, really good. I will return, but I will check the food before leaving next time. :)

Hungry for falafel? Let's go to the jewelry store! As everyone else seems to have mentioned, the charm of Oasis has diminished now that it's located in a food court instead of the jewelry mall. And I know this happened like a year ago, but I still get nostalgic about the old Oasis every once in a while. At least we will always have the happy memories... That said, the food still rocks and it's one of the best places to grab lunch in the Loop. The $4 falafel sandwich comes with lettuce, cucumbers, and tomatoes and for only $1 more they'll add hummus in there too! What a deal! I also like the chicken shawarma sandwiches...mmmm shawarma. They have specials and combo meals every day, and I don't think any of the dishes cost more than $7. UPDATE! Starting April 11, Oasis will be moving back to its original jewelry store location! Hip hip hooray!

I ate here in its old jeweler's mall location. At that time, this was my favorite falafel place in the Loop. But keep in mind my opinion is about Oasis more than a year ago. I always get extra hot sauce - what is that called? - for my falafel. I liked walking through the jeweler's mall to get to the small restaurant. There are only a couple tables for sit-in dining. The whole place seemed rather cozy and mysterious, way in the back of that jeweler's bazaar.

when the Chicago weather is warm, and begging you to do a picnic thing, get some falafel, hummus and more falafel as millennium park is just a block east. Do your tummy, tan and soul a favor and enjoy quick, cheap good eats in one of the more beautiful urban environments.  The food court is slightly getting better though not much despite the artwork on the wall as it can only do so much to diminish the bus stationesque flavor of the place. Falafel spiced just right, crispy bites into a nice and inviting middle of tasty goodness. Hummus very simple, but a great friend to the falafel and adequately filling without giving you the afternoon grease induced comas.

Really friendly service and good food. A nice break from the endless sea of fast food or sandwich joints downtown. The food court it is in is one of the strangest places to eat, with weird ass murals, odd smells from the Popeyes chicken, and dim flourescent lighting. I agree with Amy M., take it to go.

This is definitely a hidden treasure.  I got the Kafka Chicken plate and it came with rice, a salad and also a whole pita with beans on the side.  If you want big portions for cheap this is a place to go.  I am definitely going to return and I love the novelty of it being in the back of the jewelry store.  You seriously feel like it is your own hidden treasure!

This is my favorite cheap loop lunch spot, especially because the falafel is so good.  Unlike other falafel restaurants downtown, Oasis makes their sandwich just right - not too soggy and not too dry.  And for under $3.50, it's pretty amazing.

Great lunch spot in the loop. Quick service and great prices.I have also seen James Ward(Chow Chow for now guy on channel 7) there several times. Update 11/3/06-Oasis was closed for remodeling. It is now open again,under a new name-Kabob2.I have not been there yet,but was told the owners were the same. I'll try it and let you know! I did try Kabob 2-definately not the same owners-boohoo! Not awful,but not the same. Update 4/13/2008 Back in the old location! A welcome change!! Hope everything is as it was-delicious and fresh! Will try something very soon!

Moved to the 17 S Wabash food court due to renovations at the jewelers' mall; part of the attraction for me was the offbeat location amidst the bazaar of jewels. Tasty, quick food and pleasant service. The menu ventures a little further afield than the usual Lebanese with Moroccan chicken, moussaka, and foul. The competition (Haifa on Wells, that place at the State of Illinois bldg) seems cheaper and generally has better vegetarian fare, but nothing beats Sultan's Market. (FWIW, another Middle Eastern place recently opened, hermit crab-like, in its old Jewelers' Mall location.)

Love this place.  It's a great respite from all the overpriced salad and sandwich emporiums of the Loop.  It's economical and the food, while being your standard Middle Eastern hummus and shwarma, is fresh and tasty.  Service is generally fast and polite.  It's not much in the ambience department and finding a seat at lunchtime can be tricky since there aren't many tables.  If it's a nice day, get your food to go and eat in Millenium Park, which is a block away.
This is a great middle eastern cafe/restaurant.  It is located in the back of a jewellery store on jewellers row.  They have great specials and really fresh food, its a great find.

I've been going to this place for 13 years -- when your lunch choices are limited to crappy fast food chains in east Loop, this is truly an oasis, a diamond in the rough in Jeweler's Row no less, yar. Buried in the back, it's lacking in natural light and atmosphere, but the lunch specials are reasonable for what you get -- tasty if unexceptional Middle Eastern food.

This really is an oasis, as you may not find it until you realize it is in the back of the Jewelers Mall. This gem of a lunch spot has tempting Middle Eastern dishes like couscous, falafel, and baklava, a terrific break from burgers and fries.
